When alarm's property is updated with the same value, an empty record is
added to the alarm history output.

This fix omits the update to alarm history if there no changes to any
alarm property.

Closes-Bug: #1465550
(cherry picked from commit e5b3988c7cb01d2230f67c41aa76935a11b0e42a in Ceilometer)

Change-Id: I42014a1d207bb32e81e8f09b65857d0608bba675
"}]
commit_message:
Update alarm history only if change in alarm property

When alarm's property is updated with the same value, an empty record is
added to the alarm history output.

This fix omits the update to alarm history if there no changes to any
alarm property.

Closes-Bug: #1465550
(cherry picked from commit e5b3988c7cb01d2230f67c41aa76935a11b0e42a in Ceilometer)

Change-Id: I42014a1d207bb32e81e8f09b65857d0608bba675
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/aodh refs/changes/78/277578/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_redundant_update_alarm_property_no_history_change(self): alarm = self._get_alarm('a') history = self._get_alarm_history('a') self.assertEqual([], history) self.assertEqual('critical', alarm['severity']) self._update_alarm('a', dict(severity='low')) new_alarm = self._get_alarm('a') history = self._get_alarm_history('a') self.assertEqual(1, len(history)) self.assertEqual(jsonutils.dumps({'severity': 'low'}), history[0]['detail']) self.assertEqual('low', new_alarm['severity']) self._update_alarm('a', dict(severity='low')) updated_history = self._get_alarm_history('a') self.assertEqual(1, len(updated_history)) self.assertEqual(jsonutils.dumps({'severity': 'low'}), updated_history[0]['detail']) self.assertEqual(history, updated_history)

commit_message:
New 4-th group of "nightly" functional ui tests for fuel-web.

"Nodes across environment" test group:
  Node settings pop-up contains environment and node network group names
  Standard and Compact Node view support
  Quick Search support for "Equipment" page
  Quick Search results saved after refreshing of page
  Quick Search results saved after switching to other page
  Sorting support for "Equipment" page
  Filtering support for "Equipment" page
  Sorting and Filtering results saved after refreshing of page
  Sorting and Filtering results saved after switching to other page
  "Offline" node deletion from "Equipment" page
  Node groups segmentation on "Equipment" page

Change-Id: I6a6d1b4f9e6697399face92a4ddbc95f3744ee18
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/81/277081/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: /* * Copyright 2016 Mirantis, Inc. * * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may * not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain * a copy of the License at * * http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 * * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT * WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the * License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations * under the License. **/ define([ 'tests/functional/pages/modal', 'tests/functional/helpers' ], function(ModalWindow) { 'use strict'; function EquipmentLib(remote) { this.remote = remote; this.modal = new ModalWindow(remote); } EquipmentLib.prototype = { constructor: EquipmentLib, nodeSelector: 'div.node', checkNodesSegmentation: function(nodeView, nodesQuantity, provisioningFlag) { // Input array: Nodes quantity by groups. // [Total, Pending Addition (Provisioning), Discover, Error, Offline] var nodeSel = this.nodeSelector; var tempSelector = '.'; var clusterSelector = 'pending_addition'; if (nodeView === 'Compact') { nodeSel = 'div.compact-node'; tempSelector = ' div.'; } else if (nodeView !== 'Standard') { throw new Error('Invalid input value. Check nodeView: "' + nodeView + '" parameter and restart test.'); } if (provisioningFlag) { clusterSelector = 'provisioning'; } return this.remote .assertElementsAppear(nodeSel, 1000, '"' + nodeView + ' Node" view is loaded') .assertElementsExist(nodeSel, nodesQuantity[0], 'Default nodes quantity is observed') .assertElementsExist(nodeSel + tempSelector + clusterSelector, nodesQuantity[1], '"Pending Addition/Provisioning" nodes are observed in "' + nodeView + '"" view') .assertElementsExist(nodeSel + tempSelector + 'discover', nodesQuantity[2], '"Discovered" nodes are observed in "' + nodeView + '"" view') .assertElementsExist(nodeSel + tempSelector + 'error', nodesQuantity[3], '"Error" nodes are observed in "' + nodeView + '"" view') .assertElementsExist(nodeSel + tempSelector + 'offline', nodesQuantity[4], '"Offline" nodes are observed in "' + nodeView + '"" view'); }, renameNode: function(nodeSelector, newName) { var nodeNameSelector = 'div.name p'; return this.remote .assertElementsExist(nodeSelector, 'Node to rename exists') .findByCssSelector(nodeSelector) .assertElementsExist(nodeNameSelector, 'Node name textlink exists') .clickByCssSelector(nodeNameSelector) .assertElementsAppear('input.node-name-input', 500, 'Rename textfield appears') .findByCssSelector('input.node-name-input') .clearValue() .type(newName) .pressKeys('\uE007') .end() .assertElementsAppear(nodeNameSelector, 1000, 'Node new name textlink appears') .assertElementTextEquals(nodeNameSelector, newName, 'Node name is changed successfully') .end(); }, checkSearchPageSwitching: function(nodeName, pageName) { return this.remote .clickLinkByText('Equipment') .assertElementsAppear('div.equipment-page', 2000, 'Page switched successfully from ' + pageName + ' page') .assertElementsExist(this.nodeSelector, 1, 'Search result saved after switching to ' + pageName + ' page') .assertElementContainsText(this.nodeSelector, nodeName, 'Search result is correct after ' + 'switching to ' + pageName + ' page'); }, checkSortingPageSwitching: function(nodesQuantity) { // Input array: Nodes quantity by groups. // [Total, Pending Addition, Discover] return this.remote .clickLinkByText('Equipment') .assertElementsAppear('div.equipment-page', 5000, '"Equipment" page is loaded') .assertElementsExist(this.nodeSelector, nodesQuantity[0], 'Filtered nodes quantity is observed') .assertElementsExist('div.nodes-group', 2, 'Only "Pending Addition" and "Discovered" node groups are correctly filtered') .assertElementContainsText('div.nodes-group:nth-child(2) h4', 'Pending Addition', '"Pending Addition" node group is correctly sorted') .assertElementsExist('div.nodes-group:nth-child(2) div.node.pending_addition', nodesQuantity[1], 'Default quantity of "Pending Addition" nodes is observed') .assertElementContainsText('div.nodes-group:nth-child(1) h4', 'Discovered', '"Discovered" node group is correctly sorted') .assertElementsExist('div.nodes-group:nth-child(1) div.node.discover', nodesQuantity[2], 'Default quantity of "Discovered" nodes is observed'); }, checkDefaultSorting: function(sortDirection, nodesQuantity) { // Input array: Nodes quantity by groups. // [Total, Pending Addition, Discover, Error, Offline] var groupSelector = 'div.nodes-group:nth-child('; var orderName, sortOrder; if (sortDirection === 'down') { sortOrder = [1, 2, 3, 4]; orderName = 'asc'; } else if (sortDirection === 'up') { sortOrder = [4, 3, 2, 1]; orderName = 'desc'; } else { throw new Error('Invalid sort direction value. Check sortDirection: "' + sortDirection + '" parameter and restart test.'); } return this.remote .assertElementsExist('div.sort-by-status-' + orderName, 'Status sorting block is observed') .findByCssSelector('div.sort-by-status-' + orderName) .assertElementContainsText('button.btn-default', 'Status', 'Sorting by status is default') .assertElementsExist('i.glyphicon-arrow-' + sortDirection, 'Sorting in ' + orderName + ' order is observed') .end() .assertElementsExist(this.nodeSelector, nodesQuantity[0], 'Default nodes quantity is observed') .assertElementContainsText(groupSelector + sortOrder[0] + ') h4', 'Pending Addition', '"Pending Addition" node group is correctly sorted') .assertElementsExist(groupSelector + sortOrder[0] + ') div.node.pending_addition', nodesQuantity[1], 'Default quantity of "Pending Addition" nodes is observed') .assertElementContainsText(groupSelector + sortOrder[1] + ') h4', 'Discovered', '"Discovered" node group is correctly sorted') .assertElementsExist(groupSelector + sortOrder[1] + ') div.node.discover', nodesQuantity[2], 'Default quantity of "Discovered" nodes is observed') .assertElementContainsText(groupSelector + sortOrder[2] + ') h4', 'Error', '"Error" node group is correctly sorted') .assertElementsExist(groupSelector + sortOrder[2] + ') div.node.error', nodesQuantity[3], 'Default quantity of "Error" nodes is observed') .assertElementContainsText(groupSelector + sortOrder[3] + ') h4', 'Offline', '"Offline" node group is correctly sorted') .assertElementsExist(groupSelector + sortOrder[3] + ') div.node.offline', nodesQuantity[4], 'Default quantity of "Offline" nodes is observed'); } }; return EquipmentLib; });

commit_message:
Fixed some other warnings in tests, then remove tests from exclude

Fix some other warnings in tests, and then let's remove the "tests" from
tox.flake8.exclude:
 * O325 Not using translating helper for logging
 * H404  multi line docstring should start without a leading new line
 * H201  no 'except:' at least use 'except Exception:'

Change-Id: I87287b1f9f5e87add18aee2f7989da337c64ccc2
Depends-On: Ic262fa02d0e01a617e883fbdb74cec0b7957c78b

commit_message:
Add debtcollector as requirement

oslo.config imports debtcollector but does not require it.

This now leads to build failures for projects importing oslo.config
like:
http://logs.openstack.org/97/277697/1/check/gate-openstack-manuals-tox-checkniceness/1729088/console.html#_2016-02-09_06_50_36_536

Change-Id: I4c598b338592a56c8a0b447c5fdfaf3f5c2f4876

commit_message:
Prevent unexpected exception if provision fail

Two problem fixed:

- do not fail if no nodes were sent to reboot;
- in case of exception unlock nodes by uids instead of names

Change-Id: Iafe9c78e7a92c9f410c9452748b242a6fe8140e4
Closes-Bug: #1540360

commit_message:
[doc] Add documentation on package loaders and package cache

Related bp: murano-engine-package-cache

Change-Id: If97d18b86ef05a2cf40443981eb73f3c9aa26246
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/32/274632/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _manage-packages: .. toctree:: :maxdepth: 2: ================= Managing packages ================= Managing packages on engine-side ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ There are currently two ways ``murano-engine`` is able to access packages: through a local directory and through access to ``murano-api``. Accessing local packages is useful for debugging purposes and/or to save bandwidth between api and engine. Local package directories ------------------------- To define a list of directories where the engine would look for package files you should set ``load_packages_from`` option in ``packages_opts`` section inside :file:`murano.conf` config file. This option can be set to a (comma-separated) list of directory paths. Whenever an engine needs to access a package it would inspect these directories first, before accessing ``murano-api``. API package cache ----------------- Whenever ``murano-engine`` downloads a package from API it stores and unpacks it locally. Engine uses directory defined in ``packages_cache`` option in ``packages_opts`` section inside :file:`murano.conf` config file. If it is not used a temporary directory is created. ``enable_packages_cache`` option in the same section defines whether the packages would persist on disk or not. When set to ``False`` each package, downloaded from API would be stored in a separate directory, that would be deleted after the deployment (or action) is over. This means, that every deployment (or action execution )would need to download all the packages it requires, regardless of any packages downloaded previously by the engine. When set to ``True`` (default) the engine would share downloaded packages between deployments (and action executions). This means, that packages would persist on disk and would have to be eventually deleted. This is done optimistically: whenever engine requires a package and that package is not in found locally  the engine would download the package. Afterwards it would check all the previously cached packages with the same FQN and same version if the cached package is not required by any ongoing deployment it get's deleted. Otherwise it stays on disk until a new version is downloaded.

commit_message:
raise coordination error if not registered

in the scenario where an agent does not get registered in group,
try to rejoin group. if not successful after 5 attempts, give up
and raise.

also, cherry-pick I6a48cf38b24a00a0db94d3dea0c6746b52526026
Change-Id: Ic0b6b62dace88e4e1ce7932024350bb211efb9ef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/07/275707/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ceilometer.i18n import _LE, _LI, _LW def extract_my_subset(self, group_id, iterable, attempt=0): if self._my_id not in members: raise tooz.coordination.MemberNotJoined(group_id, self._my_id) except tooz.coordination.MemberNotJoined: if attempt >= 5: raise LOG.warning(_LW('Cannot extract tasks because agent failed to ' 'join group properly. Rejoining group.')) self.join_group(group_id) return self.extract_my_subset(group_id, iterable, attempt + 1)
deleted_lines: from ceilometer.i18n import _LE, _LI def extract_my_subset(self, group_id, iterable):

commit_message:
Drop branch selection on oslo-master periodic job

Periodic jobs cannot have a branch selection. So fix
the branch to always use master.

Change-Id: Ida35e8f8fe5a631e12e77936325e557acef91a35

commit_message:
Replace deprecated library function os.popen() with subprocess

os.popen() is deprecated since version 2.6. Resolved with use of
subprocess module.

Change-Id: Ic524d0548e593a319e55b1111bec555a34de0b19
Closes-Bug: #1529836

Fix parsing multiline ini files

Resolves bug: 1543104
Resolves bug: 1541931

Change-Id: Ic85792819fa382282a29bd2b9a62fe21aff63791

added_lines: string = """unset OS_DOMAIN_NAME res = config.osrc_parse(string) def test_ini(self): string = """# This is a comment line # host = 127.0.0.1 port = 3306 user = openstack password = 'aNiceQuotedPassword' password2 = "aNiceQuotedPassword" spaced = value""" res = config.ini_parse(string) self.assertEqual('127.0.0.1', res['host']) self.assertEqual('openstack', res['user']) self.assertEqual('3306', res['port']) self.assertEqual('aNiceQuotedPassword', res['password']) self.assertEqual('aNiceQuotedPassword', res['password2']) self.assertEqual('value', res['spaced'])

commit_message:
Remove astute.yaml and use them as fixtures

* Set fixtures default for the fuel_noop_tests.rb
* If bundler required, run bundle install/update before
  the "rake spec_prep" command in the fuel_noop_tests.rb
* Add docs for external astute.yaml noop fixtures

DocImpact: Noop tests framework dev docs

commit_message:
Prevent concurrent initialisation of the mechanism driver.

A recent FV run managed to get two concurrent initialisations
resulting in spammy error logs, if not incorrect behaviour.

Let's just use a lock to avoid getting this wrong.

Change-Id: I2d1f6b42e27ed5690d1620f5dbc26c5aa03fa4f9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-calico refs/changes/87/269587/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

LOG.warning("PID changed from %s to %s; unexpected fork after " "initialisation. Reinitialising Calico driver.", self._my_pid, current_pid) # (Re)init the DB. self.db = None self._get_db() # Admin context used by (only) the thread that updates Felix agent # status. self._agent_update_context = ctx.get_admin_context() # Get RPC connection for fanning out Felix state reports. try: state_report_topic = topics.REPORTS except AttributeError: # Older versions of OpenStack share the PLUGIN topic. state_report_topic = topics.PLUGIN self.state_report_rpc = agent_rpc.PluginReportStateAPI( state_report_topic ) # Use Etcd-based transport. if self.transport: # If we've been forked then the old transport will incorrectly # share file handles with the other process. subject: Fix typo in keystone v3 creation dict
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-08 14:55:41.000000000', 'files': ['freezer/apiclient/client.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/freezer/commit/0d5e1fdf06d33f8daf5de89c306ba3963dc3c51e', 'message': 'Fix typo in keystone v3 creation dict

There is a misconfigured parameters when freezer client tries to create a
keystone instance for version 3 using tokens in which project_name and
project_domain_name are expecting values that does not exists

Closes-bug: 1543156

Change-Id: Ic1baea868e8b7d64fd3cb803e0637225a4a82d46
'}]
commit_message:
Fix typo in keystone v3 creation dict

There is a misconfigured parameters when freezer client tries to create a
keystone instance for version 3 using tokens in which project_name and
project_domain_name are expecting values that does not exists

Closes-bug: 1543156

Change-Id: Ic1baea868e8b7d64fd3cb803e0637225a4a82d46
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/freezer refs/changes/32/277432/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: verify=True): self.opts.user_domain_name = user_domain_name if project_domain_name: self.opts.project_domain_name = project_domain_name

commit_message:
Refactoring of the Noop tests framework

Change-Id: I75296e55a807c55e450d55990b208754874ad07d
Fuel-CI: disable

deleted_lines: class Noop module Spec def resource_test_template(binding) template = <<-'eof' it do expect(subject).to contain_<%= resource.type.gsub('::', '__').downcase %>('<%= resource.title %>').with( <% max_length = resource.to_hash.keys.inject(0) { |ml, key| key = key.to_s; ml = key.size if key.size > ml; ml } -%> <% resource.each do |parameter, value| -%> <%= ":#{parameter}".to_s.ljust(max_length + 1) %> => <%= value.inspect %>, <% end -%> ) end eof ERB.new(template, nil, '-').result(binding) end def catalog_to_spec(context) catalog = context.subject catalog = catalog.call if catalog.is_a? commit_message:
Redundent if Statement

The 'if' statement is redundant, because __getattr__ method only gets
invoked for attributes that are not in the __dict__ attribute, therefore,
if __getattr__ is called it means that the attribute is not in __dict__

Change-Id: I68b975c2e03395db90d421e3180cea81e9af271b

commit_message:
Remove g-search from devstack

The g-search service was promoted to its own project and it's now called
Searchlight. This patch removes that code from devstack.

Change-Id: I9dd7ce62f0339911e025329b8a841792219ea02b

commit_message:
Set new ml2::ovs parameters to use service default

New parameters should be set to $::os_service_default when possible.
This is especially important since restarting the OVS agent will drop
all flows in releases before Liberty and on Liberty if
drop_flows_on_start is true.

Change-Id: I7a406a7f24e95d5ce18fd52a0b15d4be72d615e2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/36/230536/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add spec for grenade resources.sh checks

Grenade plugins provide a resources.sh file which can be used to
create resources and verify that they survive across the grenade
upgrade gap. We'd like that so let's do it.

Change-Id: I2aa797ba4ca4b9eb0a95956c3edd8a91e325426b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/08/229008/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================= Grenade Resource Checks ======================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/grenade-resource-checks In the Liberty cycle ceilometer was removed from the core of the grenade upgrade testing tool into a plugin as described by the `grenade plugins`_ documentation. The pre-existing functionality was maintained so very little testing is done other than simple sanity checking to confirm that the expected processes are running. Grenade provides a ``resources.sh`` mechanism which makes it possible to create and confirm resources that are relevant to ceilometer. This spec proposes to add these resources checks to the ceilometer grenade runs. Problem description =================== If we take all the various parts used to make a working ceilometer system (pollsters, notification agents, transformers, collectors, dispatchers, storage systems) and then in the maturing aodh and gnocchi tools it is clear the overall system is quite complex to upgrade and verify. We can use grenade more effectively to test that upgrades are correct with each commit. In 2014 grenade briefly had a tool called ``javelin`` which allowed confirmation of resources surviving over the upgrade gap. This was demonstrated to be insufficiently flexible for the emerging world of devstack and grenade plugins so the ``resources.sh`` model was chosen as the preferred tool. The `grenade plugins`_ information explains how it works. Ceilometer can use this tooling in its grenade jobs. Not just with pure ceilometer upgrades, but also upgrades involving aodh and gnocchi. Proposed change =============== The proposed change here is to incrementally develop a ``resources.sh`` in the ``devstack/upgrade`` directory of the ceilometer repo. This file will create a variety of resources in the base devstack and then confirm that expected meters and events are recorded in that same devstack and still present in the target devstack. When javelin was used this resource validation was as simple as adding a single instance via nova, waiting on some measures from notifications, doing the upgrade and then checking for new measures from the same instance. Future iterations could add (assuming suitable upgrade paths were paved): * Upgrades to aodh and the concomitant tests of alarms being present and alarming functionality continuing to have correct behavior. * Upgrades to gnocchi with confirmation that metrics previously recorded in ceilometer's storage now have measures in gnocchi's storage. Alternatives ------------ While grenade provides a useful framework for these kinds of tests, it might make sense for the cases that involved aodh and gnocchi to use something custom. Doing this would be unfortunate; we should bend grenade to our will and where it will not we should fix grenade. We want to encourage the kind of repo splitting and tooling separation that we've done with aodh and gnocchi. Grenade will need to support this kind of thing sooner than later. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Pipeline impact --------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Except for the fact that better testing will find bugs and fixed bugs make happier users. Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- As new activities and resources are added to the ceilometer environment it may be useful to add additional tests to the resources.sh tests. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: chdent Other contributors: you Ongoing maintainer: The ceilometer team Work Items ---------- * Determine the base list of resources/metrics that need to be created and tested for surviving the upgrade. * Create a resources.sh which creates and verifies those resources according to the stages described in `grenade plugins`_ documentation. Future lifecycle ================ As stated above in "developer impact": regular review of the grenade tests will be required to ensure that the test cover appropriate resources. The ceilometer team will be responsible for this work. Dependencies ============ * `grenade plugins`_ Testing ======= Now that ceilometer uses a grenade plugin, this change can be tested simply by changing that plugin. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== * `grenade plugins`_ .. _grenade plugins: https://github.com/openstack-dev/grenade/blob/master/PLUGINS.rst

commit_message:
repos: update ceph repo apt pin url

A recent change [1] modified the default ceph repo from ceph.com to
download.ceph.com.

This patch aims to update the apt pin configuration so we download
packages from there and not from UCA.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/puppet-ceph/commit/c59467369dd2e6f54ed9a7d94176f8639941b8f5

Change-Id: Iff1924cf4ddda67fe9519c971eba0603453bf100

commit_message:
Wrap ntpdate to timeout

As have some problems with retry hanging ntpdate outside,
wrap it to timeout with preserve status to better exit code
manage.

Change-Id: I9a4210d7cf11d59e8e6bfe3a5e525e2cd5e8367f
Closes-Bug: #1533082
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/15/273515/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cmd: timeout --foreground --preserve-status 30 ntpdate -u -v -s $(awk '/^server/ { if ($2 !~ /127\.127\.[0-9]+\.[0-9]+/) {ORS=" "; print $2}}' /etc/ntp.conf)

subject: Remove all 'validate_array' statements
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-14 11:07:17.000000000', 'files': ['manifests/cluster/zookeeper.pp', 'manifests/cluster/cassandra.pp', 'manifests/network/midonet/api.pp', 'manifests/network/midonet/agent.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo/commit/44cd7265a82d8a9cdff16fa57061523cbf1d33e9', 'message': "Remove all 'validate_array' statements

Unfortunately, some distributions like CentOS 7 (I guess RedHat 7 as
well) still using puppet < 3.7, which experience the annoying 'PUP-1299'
bug:

https://tickets.puppetlabs.com/browse/PUP-1299

So passing a single array element, it magically transforms to a string
(or whatever the inside elements are) and the validate_array fails. We
need to get rid of these validations.

Change-Id: Icc22ee575b7c236d1a6358f8593cf813d339a4b5
(cherry picked from commit 7260c13fbeac8bf34da30d70f449412f3628e2f7)
"}]
commit_message:
Remove all 'validate_array' statements

Unfortunately, some distributions like CentOS 7 (I guess RedHat 7 as
well) still using puppet < 3.7, which experience the annoying 'PUP-1299'
bug:

https://tickets.puppetlabs.com/browse/PUP-1299

So passing a single array element, it magically transforms to a string
(or whatever the inside elements are) and the validate_array fails. We
need to get rid of these validations.

Change-Id: Icc22ee575b7c236d1a6358f8593cf813d339a4b5
(cherry picked from commit 7260c13fbeac8bf34da30d70f449412f3628e2f7)

commit_message:
[Core-Library] Add ability to specify direction and ethetype for groups

Previously there was no way to specify in which direction security rule
should be applied, only ingress was supported. Also it was impossible
to create IPv6 rules.
This patch added ability to specify direction and ethertype for
Neutron security groups and direction - for AWS security groups

Change-Id: Iba5be7a8a94c34eab3e0e06f95e5358a84a5dd7b
Closes-Bug: #1532317
(cherry picked from commit 186612daf708b0ad3199bbf77ea8d3ed0f5eb48e)

commit_message:
enginefacade: remove 'get_session' and 'get_api_session'

Removed 'get_session' and 'get_api_session' methods which were
needed for backward compatibility. Cleanup with 'save' method.
Fixed 'xen_api' tests to use Instance object instead of Instance
db model.

Implements: blueprint new-oslodb-enginefacade

Co-Authored-By: Sergey Nikitin <snikitin@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I5367f4495b060171afe9a2ddaebeb4c43fb6af78

commit_message:
docker-logs added to snapshot

We have an issue in Shotgun with copy log subdirectories log into
snapshot, when exclude is used for dir in settings.yaml.
As hotfix we restore configuration for docker-logs in the Nailgun
settings.yaml.

Change-Id: Ifc1699f67981484ff44eefb92c5a2f9d8fa5997d
Closes-Bug: #1541390

commit_message:
Fixes incorrect endpoint_override handling

When both session and endpoint_override parameters
were passed to the Client a TypeError exception was raised
because the parameter was expected to be the first one
in positional args but **kwargs were also passed to the
SessionClient

Change-Id: Iba0786a4f81d25dbfaf2b10791ddc6190deb81f2
Closes-Bug: #1543090
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-muranoclient refs/changes/61/277361/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: parameters = { 'endpoint_override': endpoint, 'session': session, 'auth': auth, 'interface': endpoint_type, 'service_type': service_type, 'region_name': region_name, 'service_name': service_name, 'user_agent': 'python-muranoclient', } parameters.update(kwargs) return SessionClient(**parameters)
deleted_lines: return SessionClient(endpoint_override=endpoint, session=session, auth=auth, interface=endpoint_type, service_type=service_type, region_name=region_name, service_name=service_name, user_agent='python-muranoclient', **kwargs)

commit_message:
Load kernel modules if needed

Add new parameters which make l23network module more flexible in cases
when it is needed to do nothing with modules or manage them outside this
module.
Tests were corrected with passing default values because exported
k_mod resources are not working correctly.

Change-Id: I191852c54d2e9b6d1227194e2b907b7d035eb0d7
Closes-bug: #1541028

commit_message:
Set https connection verify flag from config

It was not a good idea to set verify=False for all https connection.
It's better to parse value from config and set verify flag with it.

Change-Id: Ied057aba6dc23024561f349130ab862b1ddddd60

commit_message:
better support notification coordination

when launching multiple agents at same time, there is a chance that
agents will miss the registry of another agent. this is possible
because there is a lot of overhead involved when starting up agents,
specifically with initialising managers.

this change makes it so the agent only joins the group AFTER it has
done all setup that does not require coordination. after it joins,
we start listening right away for other changes to group membership

additionally, this adds a lock to pipeline queue setup so only one
event at any time can trigger a reconfiguration.

Change-Id: I8100160a3aa83a190c4110e6e8be9b26aef8fd1c
Closes-Bug: #1533787
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/93/272693/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- critical: - > [`bug 1533787 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+bug/1533787>`_] Fix an issue where agents are not properly getting registered to group when multiple notification agents are deployed. This can result in bad transformation as the agents are not coordinated. It is still recommended to set heartbeat_timeout_threshold = 0 in [oslo_messaging_rabbit] section when deploying multiple agents.

commit_message:
Fix bashisms

There's 3 scripts which include bashisms, which would fail in Debian,
where the default shell interpreter for sh is dash, and not bash.
This patch fixes these bashisms. It also fixes the wrong interpreter
path in iser_rename.erb.

Change-Id: Ic3415e3d07bc9dce1af2fbdf7fdbfead5264d788
Closes-Bug: #1542971

Provide public API's for the methods:
    - _process_create_allowed_address_pairs
    - _check_update_has_allowed_address_pairs
    - _check_update_deletes_allowed_address_pairs

This is part of the blueprint better-defined-apis

Change-Id: I2948df2ea3fdbdbb70cb78816cc171cecba3fa2e

commit_message:
Switch non-infra Ansible roles to using 'linters' tox target

This patch implements a change from individual pep8/ansible-lint/etc
lint jobs to using a unified 'linters' tox target.

This reduces nodepool usage across all OpenStack-Ansible and some
other Ansible role repositories.

Change-Id: If9979dc0cad8418bedf7a342754ab68394e0a214

commit_message:
Don't require trollius on Python 3.4 and newer

On Python 3.4 and newer, gnocchi.statsd uses asyncio of the Python
standard library.

Change-Id: Ifc6ed23ff3f00cf1096bf7f6ca2f8107a72f11f7

commit_message:
Remove tooz testing of etcd/consul on liberty or kilo

These drivers didn't exist in either of these releases
so testing against them will always fail, so just avoid
testing them in the first place.

Change-Id: Iae56e82f907222fd1698520b21e112319db247ca

commit_message:
Adds validation for Ironic gateway

Currently, there is no backend validation for Ironic gateway.
Added intersection check.

Change-Id: I89dcf9414f11ccffd85e1b10b559bd8cae78a935
Closes-Bug: #1522386
Signed-off-by: Ruslan Aliev <raliev@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Use all available ipaddresses as SAN for master nginx

As master node nginx must be acceccible from any network it has
and nginx listen on every interface, all IP addresses from them
must be used in TLS certificate for proper connection.

Change-Id: Ib7121af26fffbe011a616b3ffdabb45dc273c3ce
Closes-Bug: #1517893

commit_message:
Add LXD experimental Tempest job for Manila

New driver (LXC/LXD) is going to be added to Manila.
So, register new Tempest job for it.
Make it run only for M+ branches in experimental pipeline
and only as nonvoting until it is merged and becomes stable.

Change-Id: I81d9ecaf3cfb62adafea7e5e038b0ab91d952119

commit_message:
Add ZFSonLinux experimental Tempest job for Manila

New driver ZFSonLinux is going to be added to Manila project.
So, register new Tempest job for it.
Make it run only for M+ branches in experimental pipeline
and only as nonvoting until it is merged and becomes stable.

Change-Id: Ic675c5dfa772d47c02d16257ed0eefc286facd03

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ When a cloud user requests to launch an instance, that request contains two different types of information: requested resource amounts and requested capabilities that the target host should (or must) have. All resources -- even seemingly complex ones like NUMA cells -- can be decomposed into simple amounts (integer or float) of some unit. It's important to remember that comparing inventories of resources is *not* the same thing as the logic required to *place* a particular request on a target host. Placement logic takes into account both the quantitative parts of the request (resources) as well as the qualitative parts of the request (capabilities) and determines the hosts that have the available inventory to satisfy the requested quantities of resources as well as the capabilities contained in the qualitative part of the request. The classes in this module model only the part of the launch request that deals with quantitative things: the resources that the user wishes to consume and the capacity and usage records for those resource quantities. """ from nova.objects import base @base.NovaObjectRegistry.register class Resource(base.NovaObject): """A requested amount of some resource.""" # Version 1.0: Initial version VERSION = '1.0' fields = { 'resource_class': obj_fields.ResourceClassField(), 'amount': obj_fields.IntegerField(), } @base.NovaObjectRegistry.register class ResourceList(base.ObjectListBase, base.NovaObject): """A set of requested amounts of resources.""" # Version 1.0: Initial Version VERSION = '1.0' fields = { 'objects': fields.ListOfObjectsField('Resource'), } @base.NovaObjectRegistry.register class ResourceCapacity(base.NovaObject): """A record of the amount of a particular resource a provider provides. Inventories are simply the record of the capacity of a provider of some resource along with some information about the extent to which that resource provider can deal with requests for amounts of that resource. """ # Version 1.0: Initial version VERSION = '1.0' fields = { # The type of resource 'resource_class': obj_fields.ResourceClassField(), # The total physical capacity that the resource provider has for # this type of resource. 'total': obj_fields.IntegerField(), # A multiplier that allows a resource provider to overcommit a # particular type of resource. 'allocation_ratio': obj_fields.FloatField(), # The minimum amount of this type of resource that the resource # provider can fulfill for a single request. 'min_unit': obj_fields.IntegerField(), # The maximum amount of this type of resource that the resource # provider can fulfill for a single request. 'max_unit': obj_fields.IntegerField(), } @base.NovaObjectRegistry.register class ResourceUsage(base.NovaObject): """A record of the amount of a particular resource used by a consumer.""" # Version 1.0: Initial version VERSION = '1.0' fields = { # Who is the consumer of this resource? This will typically be # an instance UUID 'consumer_id': obj_fields.StringField(), # The type of resource 'resource_class': obj_fields.ResourceClassField(), # The total physical capacity that the resource provider has for # this type of resource. 'used': obj_fields.IntegerField(), }

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Resource pools are entities that share some amount of a particular class of resource. """ from nova.objects import base from nova.objects import fields as obj_fields @base.NovaObjectRegistry.register class ResourcePool(base.NovaObject): # Version 1.0: Initial version VERSION = '1.0' fields = { 'uuid': obj_field.UUIDField(), # A name for the shared resource pool. added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Resource providers are entities that expose an inventory of resources that may be consumed by requesting users. Each resource provider also publishes a set of capabilities that the provider has. """ from nova import objects from nova.i18n import _LE from nova.objects import base @base.NovaObjectRegistry.register class ResourceProvider(base.NovaObject): # Version 1.0: Initial version VERSION = '1.0' fields = { 'id': obj_fields.StringField(), # The collection of capacity information for all quantitative # resources that the provider allows to be consumed. 'capacity': obj_fields.ListOfObjectsField('ResourceCapacity'), # The usage records of each amount of resources consumed. 'usage': obj_fields.ListOfObjectsField('ResourceUsage'), } def set_capacity(self, capacity): """Set capacity information for a type of resource. :note The resource provider's state is not persisted until the save() method is called. :param capacity: `nova.objects.ResourceCapacity` object for a particular resource class. """ if not isinstance(capacity, objects.ResourceCapacity): nsg = _LE("Expected ResourceCapacity object. Got %r") msg = msg % type(capacity)) raise TypeError(msg) for cap_obj in self.capacity.objects: if cap_obj.resource_class == capacity.resource_class: self.capacity.objects.remove(cap_obj) self.capacity.objects.append(capacity) def

commit_message:
Adds resource_classes lookup table to API DB

Adds a simple lookup table for resource classes to the API database.

Since this is a lookup table only, it doesn't need TimestampMixin, so I
changed the default base metaclass for API DB models to not base on
TimestampMixin.

Change-Id: I2ea80a4cd60fb86c5169812920455e2fdd747fee
Blueprint: resource-providers

commit_message:
WIP: Adds ResourceClass object

This patch adds the ResourceClass nova object.

Change-Id: Ica44f3e5e0cb56be70fefc10e27c1d6c3b768f0c
blueprint: resource-providers
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/78/253078/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock import testtools from nova import objects from nova.tests.unit.objects import test_objects @mock.patch('oslo_db.sqlalchemy.enginefacade._TransactionFactory.' '_create_session') class ResourceClassTestBase(testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(ResourceClassTestBase, self).setUp() self.sess = mock.MagicMock() # Mocks representing the SQLAlchemy query object returned from various # calls on the query object itself. The methods on the query object, # such as limit(), and order_by() all return the query object itself, # allowing call chaining. query_mock = mock.MagicMock() query_mock.first.return_value = query_mock query_mock.filter_by.return_value = query_mock self.sess.query.return_value = query_mock self.query = query_mock def test_get_by_name_not_found(self, sess_mock): sess_mock.return_value = self.sess self.query.first.return_value = None self.assertRaises(exception.ResourceClassNotFound, objects.ResourceClass.get_by_name, 'noexist') self.query.filter_by.assert_called_once_with(name='noexist') self.query.first.assert_called_once_with() class TestResourceClassObject(test_objects._LocalTest, ResourceClassTestBase): pass class TestRemoteResourceClassObject(test_objects._RemoteTest, ResourceClassTestBase): pass

commit_message:
Adds ResourceClass field type definition

Adds a new Enum field type definition for the class of resources that
will be handled in the resource providers system.

Resources are simple quantities of some consumable thing. Resource
classes are the types of those resources that may be requested by a user
when launching an instance.

Change-Id: Iea44ed125c378d5712e89201d76261b6ead0ae2e
Blueprint: resource-providers
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/76/253076/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ResourceClass(Enum): VCPU = "vcpu" MEMORY = "memory" DISK = "disk" PCI_GENERIC = "pci.generic" PCI_SRIOV_PF = "pci.sriovpf" PCI_SRIOV_VF = "pci.sriovvf" CPU_SOCKETS = "cpu.sockets" CPU_CORES = "cpu.cores" CPU_THREADS = "cpu.threads" ALL = ( VCPU, MEMORY, DISK, PCI_GENERIC, PCI_SRIOV_PF, PCI_SRIOV_VF, CPU_SOCKETS, CPU_CORES, CPU_THREADS, ) def __init__(self): super(ResourceClass, self).__init__( valid_values=ResourceClass.ALL) class ResourceClassField(BaseEnumField): AUTO_TYPE = ResourceClass()

subject: Adds resource classes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-16 16:57:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0ead619b068faf52dee8b06b3bb5f429aeecb5c8', 'message': 'Adds resource type classes

A set of resource types is added in /nova/resources/types.py. Simple
integer-based resources like CPU, RAM, and LocalDisk are included, in
addition to complex resources like NUMATopology, which uses the
primitives in nova.virt.hardware in order to update usage amounts and
calculate whether a requested NUMATopology for a to-be-launched instance
would fit in the NUMA cells advertised and used on a compute node.

A base nova.resources.types.ResourceType class is used as a generic
class interface for any resource, simple or complex, to create
nova.resources.amounts.AmountSpec and UsageSpec objects that can be used
to represent concrete amount and usage records. The idea here is to have
a single way of modeling some resource that is provided by a compute
node, and a single way of comparing a requested amount of something with
the capacity and usage records of the provider of that resource.
The next patch in the series adds methods to nova.objects.ComputeNode
that allow its resources (RAM, CPU, LocalDisk, PCI devices, NUMA cells,
etc) to be queried as nova.resource.amounts.UsageSpec objects.

Change-Id: I72ccdb8c54438d99f131bfb8402dec372fd1460f
Partially-implements: resource-objects

A set of resource classes is added in /nova/resources.py. Simple
integer-based resources like CPU, RAM, and LocalDisk are included, in
addition to complex resources like NUMATopology, which uses the
objects in nova.objects.numa in order to update usage amounts and

instance would fit in the NUMA cells advertised and used on a compute
node.

A base nova.resources.Resource class is used as a generic class
interface for any resource, simple or complex, to create concrete
amount and inventory records. The idea here is to have a single way
of modeling some resource that is provided by a compute node, and a
single way of comparing a requested amount of something with
the capacity and usage records of the provider of that resource.

that allow its resources (RAM, CPU, LocalDisk, PCI devices, NUMA

commit_message:
Adds resource classes

A set of resource classes is added in /nova/resources.py. Simple
integer-based resources like CPU, RAM, and LocalDisk are included, in
addition to complex resources like NUMATopology, which uses the
objects in nova.objects.numa in order to update usage amounts and
calculate whether a requested NUMATopology for a to-be-launched
instance would fit in the NUMA cells advertised and used on a compute
node.

A base nova.resources.Resource class is used as a generic class
interface for any resource, simple or complex, to create concrete
amount and inventory records. The idea here is to have a single way
of modeling some resource that is provided by a compute node, and a
single way of comparing a requested amount of something with
the capacity and usage records of the provider of that resource.

The next patch in the series adds methods to nova.objects.ComputeNode
that allow its resources (RAM, CPU, LocalDisk, PCI devices, NUMA
cells, etc) to be queried as nova.resource.Resource objects.

Change-Id: I72ccdb8c54438d99f131bfb8402dec372fd1460f
Partially-implements: resource-objects
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/99/128999/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from nova.resources import amounts from nova.resources import types from nova import test from nova.virt import hardware as hw class TestTypes(test.NoDBTestCase): def test_basic_types(self): for res_type in (types.RAM, types.CPU, types.LocalDisk): wanted = res_type.make_amount(2) self.assertIsInstance(wanted, amounts.IntegerAmount) usage = res_type.make_usage(12, 4) self.assertIsInstance(usage, amounts.IntegerUsage) def test_numa_topology(self): cap_top = hw.VirtNUMALimitTopology([ hw.VirtNUMATopologyCellLimit( 0, set([0, 1, 2, 3]), 1024, 4, 1024), hw.VirtNUMATopologyCellLimit( 1, set([4, 6]), 1024, 2, 512) ]) host_top = hw.VirtNUMAHostTopology([ hw.VirtNUMATopologyCellUsage(0, set([0, 1, 2, 3]), 1024), hw.VirtNUMATopologyCellUsage(1, set([4, 6]), 512) ]) inst_top = hw.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology([ hw.VirtNUMATopologyCell(0, set([0, 1, 2]), 256), hw.VirtNUMATopologyCell(1, set([4]), 256), ]) wanted = types.NUMATopology.make_amount(inst_top) self.assertIsInstance(wanted, amounts.NUMAAmount) usage = types.NUMATopology.make_usage(cap_top, host_top) self.assertIsInstance(usage, amounts.NUMAUsage)

subject: Add object models for comparing resource amounts
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-16 16:34:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/900680027854141c2943a7318c064766171a5fa7', 'message': 'Add object models for comparing resource amounts

Right now, we have 4 distinct ways (!) of comparing resources in the
resource tracker:

- Straight integer amounts stored in top-level key/value pairs in the
  nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker.old_resources dictionary
  attribute. For example: {"local_gb": X, "local_gb_used": Y}

- NUMA topology amounts and usages are stored as a serialized
  nova.virt.hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology/VirtNUMAHostTopology
  pair in the old_resources dictionary under the 'numa_topology'
  key: {"numa_topology": JSON-BLOB}

- PCI device amounts and usages are separately tracked by the
  nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker.pci_tracker object. This
  really is quite silly, and duplicates a ton of comparison functionality
  from both NUMA and the standard integer amount/usage stuff. The results
  of this pci_tracker work is placed into the "pci_devices" and
  "pci_passthrough_devices" (no idea why it was necessary to have two keys
  here...) as a JSON-serialized BLOB of information that comes directly from
  the pci_stats field in the compute_nodes table.

- The "extensible resource tracker" places "stuff" into a "stats" key in
  the top-level old_resources dictionary attribute. The "stuff" is a
  collection of free-form, unstructured, and undocumented amount
  information for whatever resource classes happen to be included by the
  deployer.

Just like we have 4 distinct ways of comparing resource amounts, we have
four totally different ways of comparing capacity of a resource with the
used amount of that resource:

- Straight integer amounts are compared using a simple `(total - used) >
  requested` formula.

- NUMA topology usage records use a set of classes that derive from
  nova.virt.hardware.VirtNUMATopology that enable different usage and cell
  topologies to be compared for fit.  Unfortunately, the
  VirtNUMAHostTopology object inherited the nova.compute.claim.Claim
  object's claim_test() method, which tightly couples the (supposedly
  non-coupled) nova.virt.hardware classes to the Claim interface in the
  resource tracker.

- PCI device resource usages are managed in yet another completely
  different way, using the code in nova.pci.pci_manager.PciManager, which
  is a member of the resource tracker's pci_tracker attribute.

- And still yet the extensible resource tracker plugins offer another
  way of calculating and storing usage records: in a JSON blob that is
  passed from one plugin to another, with the plugin expected to update
  the supplied dictionary with a usage record that only it understands.

This patch adds the basic object models that will enable us to have a
single interface for comparing resource amounts and usages.  It adds
some helper classes in /nova/resources/amounts.py that allow any
"amount" of a resource to be specified using the same generalized class,
and any capacity/usage of any resource to be both updated and check
for available room for a requested amount of some resource -- again,
all in a consistent generalized class interface.  The next patch in
the series adds the actual resource types that utilize the AmountSpec
and UsageSpec objects introduced in this patch.

Change-Id: I0261bf3a252fac657496c62790818d24871678e1
Partially-implements: resource-objects

'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-01-18 15:49:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/83030092eb719eef00042d944b5b1a3eaf03ed0a', 'message': 'Add object models for comparing resource amounts

Right now, we have 4 distinct ways (!) of comparing resources in the
resource tracker:

- Straight integer amounts stored in top-level key/value pairs in the
  nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker.old_resources dictionary
  attribute. For example: {"local_gb": X, "local_gb_used": Y}

- NUMA topology amounts and usages are stored as a serialized
  nova.virt.hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology/VirtNUMAHostTopology
  pair in the old_resources dictionary under the 'numa_topology'
  key: {"numa_topology": JSON-BLOB}

- PCI device amounts and usages are separately tracked by the
  nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker.pci_tracker object. This
  really is quite silly, and duplicates a ton of comparison functionality
  from both NUMA and the standard integer amount/usage stuff. The results
  of this pci_tracker work is placed into the "pci_devices" and
  "pci_passthrough_devices" (no idea why it was necessary to have two keys
  here...) as a JSON-serialized BLOB of information that comes directly from
  the pci_stats field in the compute_nodes table.

- The "extensible resource tracker" places "stuff" into a "stats" key in
  the top-level old_resources dictionary attribute. The "stuff" is a
  collection of free-form, unstructured, and undocumented amount
  information for whatever resource classes happen to be included by the
  deployer.

Just like we have 4 distinct ways of comparing resource amounts, we have
four totally different ways of comparing capacity of a resource with the
used amount of that resource:

- Straight integer amounts are compared using a simple `(total - used) >
  requested` formula.

- NUMA topology usage records use a set of classes that derive from
  nova.virt.hardware.VirtNUMATopology that enable different usage and cell
  topologies to be compared for fit.  Unfortunately, the
  VirtNUMAHostTopology object inherited the nova.compute.claim.Claim
  object's claim_test() method, which tightly couples the (supposedly
  non-coupled) nova.virt.hardware classes to the Claim interface in the
  resource tracker.

- PCI device resource usages are managed in yet another completely
  different way, using the code in nova.pci.pci_manager.PciManager, which
  is a member of the resource tracker's pci_tracker attribute.

- And still yet the extensible resource tracker plugins offer another
  way of calculating and storing usage records: in a JSON blob that is
  passed from one plugin to another, with the plugin expected to update
  the supplied dictionary with a usage record that only it understands.

This patch adds the basic object models that will enable us to have a
single interface for comparing resource amounts and usages.  It adds
four new nova.objects object classes in /nova/objects/resources.py that
allow any "amount" of a resource to be specified using the same
generalized class, and any capacity/usage of any resource to be both
updated and check for available room for a requested amount of some
resource -- again, all in a consistent generalized class interface.  The
next patch in the series adds the actual resource types that utilize the
AmountSpec and UsageSpec objects introduced in this patch.

Change-Id: I0261bf3a252fac657496c62790818d24871678e1
Partially-implements: resource-objects

'}, {'number': 14, 'created': '2015-07-22 19:02:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d9ebc0504bfae01d35a49ae9c389800def0bb9c0', 'message': 'Add object models for comparing resource amounts

Right now, we have 4 distinct ways (!) of comparing resources in
the resource tracker:

- Straight integer amounts stored in top-level key/value pairs in the
  nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker.old_resources
  dictionary attribute.
  For example: {"local_gb": X, "local_gb_used": Y}

- NUMA topology amounts and usages are stored as a serialized
  nova.virt.hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology/VirtNUMAHostTopology
  pair in the old_resources dictionary under the 'numa_topology'
  key: {"numa_topology": JSON-BLOB}

- PCI device amounts and usages are separately tracked by the
  nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker.pci_tracker object.
  This really is quite silly, and duplicates a ton of comparison
  functionality from both NUMA and the standard integer amount/usage
  stuff. The results of this pci_tracker work is placed into the
  "pci_devices" and "pci_passthrough_devices" (no idea why it was
  necessary to have two keys here...) as a JSON-serialized BLOB of
  information that comes directly from the pci_stats field in the
  compute_nodes table.

- The "extensible resource tracker" places "stuff" into a "stats" key
  in the top-level old_resources dictionary attribute. The "stuff" is
  a collection of free-form, unstructured, and undocumented amount
  information for whatever resource classes happen to be included by
  the deployer.

Just like we have 4 distinct ways of comparing resource amounts, we
have four totally different ways of comparing capacity of a resource
with the used amount of that resource:

- Straight integer amounts are compared using a simple
  `(total - used) >  requested` formula.

- NUMA topology usage records use a set of classes that in the
  `nova.objects.numa` module that enable different usage and cell
  topologies to be compared for fit.

- PCI device resource usages are managed in yet another completely
  different way, using the code in `nova.pci.pci_manager.PciManager`,
  which is a member of the resource tracker's pci_tracker attribute.

- And still yet the extensible resource tracker plugins offer another
  way of calculating and storing usage records: in a JSON blob that is
  passed from one plugin to another, with the plugin expected to
  update the supplied dictionary with a usage record that only it
  understands.

This patch adds the basic object models that will enable us to have a
single interface for comparing resource amounts and usages.  It adds
four new nova.objects object classes in /nova/objects/resources.py
that allow any "amount" of a resource to be specified using the same
generalized class, and any capacity/usage of any resource to be both
updated and check for available room for a requested amount of some
resource -- again, all in a consistent generalized class interface.
The next patch in the series adds the actual resource types that
utilize the Amount and Inventory objects introduced in this patch.

Change-Id: I0261bf3a252fac657496c62790818d24871678e1
Partially-implements: resource-objects

'}, {'number': 23, 'created': '2015-07-28 14:29:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ff63e8f9098ed918272a8fd89e062c52ac4da707', 'message': 'Add object models for comparing resource amounts

Right now, we have 4 distinct ways (!) of comparing resources in
the resource tracker:

- Straight integer amounts stored in top-level key/value pairs in the
  nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker.old_resources
  dictionary attribute.
  For example: {"local_gb": X, "local_gb_used": Y}

- NUMA topology amounts and usages are stored as a serialized
  nova.virt.hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology/VirtNUMAHostTopology
  pair in the old_resources dictionary under the 'numa_topology'
  key: {"numa_topology": JSON-BLOB}

- PCI device amounts and usages are separately tracked by the
  nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker.pci_tracker object.
  This really is quite silly, and duplicates a ton of comparison
  functionality from both NUMA and the standard integer amount/usage
  stuff. The results of this pci_tracker work is placed into the
  "pci_devices" and "pci_passthrough_devices" (no idea why it was
  necessary to have two keys here...) as a JSON-serialized BLOB of
  information that comes directly from the pci_stats field in the
  compute_nodes table.

- The "extensible resource tracker" places "stuff" into a "stats" key
  in the top-level old_resources dictionary attribute. The "stuff" is
  a collection of free-form, unstructured, and undocumented amount
  information for whatever resource classes happen to be included by
  the deployer.

Just like we have 4 distinct ways of comparing resource amounts, we
have four totally different ways of comparing capacity of a resource
with the used amount of that resource:

- Straight integer amounts are compared using a simple
  `(total - used) >  requested` formula.

- NUMA topology usage records use a set of classes that in the
  `nova.objects.numa` module that enable different usage and cell
  topologies to be compared for fit.

- PCI device resource usages are managed in yet another completely
  different way, using the code in `nova.pci.pci_manager.PciManager`,
  which is a member of the resource tracker's pci_tracker attribute.

- And still yet the extensible resource tracker plugins offer another
  way of calculating and storing usage records: in a JSON blob that is
  passed from one plugin to another, with the plugin expected to
  update the supplied dictionary with a usage record that only it
  understands.

This patch adds the basic object models that will enable us to have a
single interface for comparing resource amounts and usages.  It adds
four new nova.objects object classes in /nova/objects/resources.py
that allow any "amount" of a resource to be specified using the same
generalized class, and any capacity/usage of any resource to be both
updated and check for available room for a requested amount of some
resource -- again, all in a consistent generalized class interface.
The next patch in the series adds the actual resource types that
utilize the Amount and Inventory objects introduced in this patch.

Change-Id: I0261bf3a252fac657496c62790818d24871678e1
Partially-implements: resource-objects

commit_message:
Add object models for comparing resource amounts

Right now, we have 4 distinct ways (!) of comparing resources in
the resource tracker:

- Straight integer amounts stored in top-level key/value pairs in the
  nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker.old_resources
  dictionary attribute.
  For example: {"local_gb": X, "local_gb_used": Y}

- NUMA topology amounts and usages are stored as a serialized
  nova.virt.hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology/VirtNUMAHostTopology
  pair in the old_resources dictionary under the 'numa_topology'
  key: {"numa_topology": JSON-BLOB}

- PCI device amounts and usages are separately tracked by the
  nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker.pci_tracker object.
  This really is quite silly, and duplicates a ton of comparison
  functionality from both NUMA and the standard integer amount/usage
  stuff. The results of this pci_tracker work is placed into the
  "pci_devices" and "pci_passthrough_devices" (no idea why it was
  necessary to have two keys here...) as a JSON-serialized BLOB of
  information that comes directly from the pci_stats field in the
  compute_nodes table.

- The "extensible resource tracker" places "stuff" into a "stats" key
  in the top-level old_resources dictionary attribute. The "stuff" is
  a collection of free-form, unstructured, and undocumented amount
  information for whatever resource classes happen to be included by
  the deployer.

Just like we have 4 distinct ways of comparing resource amounts, we
have four totally different ways of comparing capacity of a resource
with the used amount of that resource:

- Straight integer amounts are compared using a simple
  `(total - used) >  requested` formula.

- NUMA topology usage records use a set of classes that in the
  `nova.objects.numa` module that enable different usage and cell
  topologies to be compared for fit.

- PCI device resource usages are managed in yet another completely
  different way, using the code in `nova.pci.pci_manager.PciManager`,
  which is a member of the resource tracker's pci_tracker attribute.

- And still yet the extensible resource tracker plugins offer another
  way of calculating and storing usage records: in a JSON blob that is
  passed from one plugin to another, with the plugin expected to
  update the supplied dictionary with a usage record that only it
  understands.

This patch adds the basic object models that will enable us to have a
single interface for comparing resource amounts and usages.  It adds
four new nova.objects object classes in /nova/objects/resources.py
that allow any "amount" of a resource to be specified using the same
generalized class, and any capacity/usage of any resource to be both
updated and check for available room for a requested amount of some
resource -- again, all in a consistent generalized class interface.
The next patch in the series adds the actual resource types that
utilize the Amount and Inventory objects introduced in this patch.

Co-Authored-By: Alexis Lee <alexisl@hp.com>
Change-Id: I0261bf3a252fac657496c62790818d24871678e1
Partially-implements: resource-objects

subject: Moved checking repository availability to astute tasks
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-02 16:22:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/38352a26c1d0613d80135f73725ac7a14240394d', 'message': 'Moved checking repository availability from pre deployment tasks to astute tasks

while the task running. Decided to move checking from http request context to
astute task, which running asynchronously.

commit_message:
Moved checking repository availability to astute tasks

Checking repositories on availability is long task.
Http request can timeouts, while the task running.
Decided to move checking from http request context to
astute task, which running asynchronously.

Depends-On: I76ed1f0b6413cc94c539d795bbba92f8e9dad50b
Depends-On: I0ccf42fd7ff05d68aa4a4aee426c1c8bfa4daea4
Closes-Bug: #1540346

Change-Id: Iff76af0b0a6573f0f8f779fda4333a3658cccc04
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/02/275302/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Show transitions initiated by API requests

This updates the state machine diagram and documentation to indicate
which transitions are initiated by API requests versus the ones that
are internally done by the conductor. Stable states are highlighted
a bit.

Change-Id: I1a2de81b14696286f1da47c06374ad235962c849
Closes-Bug: #1527316
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/99/259099/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Stable states are highlighted with a thicker border. All transitions from stable states are initiated by API requests. There are a few other API-initiated-transitions that are possible from non-stable states. The events for these API-initiated transitions are indicated with '(via API)'. Internally, the conductor initiates the other transitions (depicted in gray). .. _ironic-state-machine: http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-specs/specs/kilo-implemented/new-ironic-state-machine.html

Fixed issue with RadosGW and ceph nodes

We need to support deployments when we use Swift
for Glance images and Ceph RadosGW for S3 API.

commit_message:
Change cluster attributes pop call

cluster.attributes.editable is now MutableDict. MutableDict pop method
doesn't take default value. Method call changed to reflect this
incompability.

Change-Id: Ia2d25b4c0f3000e41958ca016a29842eb76cf196
Partial-bug: 1541005
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/40/277740/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: cluster.attributes.editable.pop(k) except KeyError: logger.warning( 'Cluster {} doesn\'t have attribute {}'.format( cluster.id, k))

commit_message:
Add baremetal API tests

This patch set adds Ironic's API:
 PUT /v1/nodes/(node_ident)/states/provision

In order to use inspection feature, make microversion 1.6.

Change-Id: Icf471962ad90621d48c8e4f82b9d9dc38c3d446f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/93/194493/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _validate_provision_state(self, node_uuid, target_state): # Validate that provision state is set within timeout start = timeutils.utcnow() while timeutils.delta_seconds( start, timeutils.utcnow()) < self.unprovision_timeout: _, node = self.client.show_node(node_uuid) if node['provision_state'] == target_state: return message = ('Failed to set provision state within ' 'the required time: %s sec.' % self.unprovision_timeout) raise exceptions.TimeoutException(message) @test.idempotent_id('6c9ce4a3-713b-4c76-91af-18c48d01f1bb') def test_set_node_provision_state(self): _, node = self.create_node(self.chassis['uuid']) provision_states_list = [ 'manage', 'inspect', 'provide', 'active', 'deleted'] target_states_list = [ 'manageable', 'manageable', 'available', 'active', 'available'] for (provision_state, target_state) in zip(provision_states_list, target_states_list): self.client.set_node_provision_state(node['uuid'], provision_state) self._validate_provision_state(node['uuid'], target_state)

commit_message:
Updated iLO documentation for boot mode capability

Updated the "Boot mode support" section to include more details about
the boot mode capability

Closes-Bug: #1540857
Change-Id: Ib0ec1bf0e308d2c761efb8b483a6edb4194f0ebd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/18/274618/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * If operator/user doesn't care about boot modes for servers, then the boot mode capability need not be configured. * When boot mode capability is not configured : If pending boot mode is set, these drivers use the pending boot mode of the bare metal proliant server as their boot mode during their next reboot. If the pending boot mode is not set, for uefi enabled servers it sets the boot mode to "uefi" by default and "bios" for the rest. * When boot mode capability is configured, the driver sets the pending boot mode to the configured value.
deleted_lines: * When boot mode capability is not configured, these drivers preserve the current boot mode of the bare metal ProLiant server. If operator/user doesn't care about boot modes for servers, then the boot mode capability need not be configured.

commit_message:
Agent vendor handles manual cleaning

Agent base vendor now supports manual cleaning. In the case of a
clean version mismatch (agent rebooted to a new version after manual
cleaning started), we continue from the current clean step instead
of (in automated cleaning) restarting from the first clean step.

Change-Id: I89726f3b32f96befba9a2e1bee67b2a7cc7eeb57
Partial-Bug: #1526290

added_lines: @mock.patch('ironic.conductor.manager.ConductorManager._spawn_worker') def _continue_node_clean_skip_step(self, mock_spawn, redo=False): # test that skipping current step mechanism works driver_info = {'clean_steps': self.clean_steps} if redo: driver_info['redo_clean_step'] = redo node = obj_utils.create_test_node( self.context, driver='fake', provision_state=states.CLEANWAIT, target_provision_state=states.MANAGEABLE, driver_internal_info=driver_info, clean_step=self.clean_steps[0]) self._start_service() self.service.continue_node_clean(self.context, node.uuid) self.service._worker_pool.waitall() node.refresh() if redo: self.assertFalse('redo_clean_step' in node.driver_internal_info) expected_steps = self.clean_steps else: expected_steps = self.next_clean_steps mock_spawn.assert_called_with(self.service._do_next_clean_step, mock.ANY, expected_steps) def test_continue_node_clean_skip_step(self): self._continue_node_clean_skip_step() def test_continue_node_clean_no_skip_step(self): self._continue_node_clean_skip_step(redo=True) def __get_node_next_clean_steps(self, skip=True): steps = self.service._get_node_next_clean_steps(task, skip_step=skip) expected = self.next_clean_steps if skip else self.clean_steps self.assertEqual(expected, steps) def test__get_node_next_clean_steps(self): self.__get_node_next_clean_steps() def test__get_node_next_clean_steps_no_skip(self): self.__get_node_next_clean_steps(skip=False)

commit_message:
Adds security_group_updated method in HyperVSecurityGroupDriver

With the changes introduced in securitygroups_rpc with the
below commit hyperv code breaks.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/147713/

Because of this, any changes in the security groups are not applied
by the HyperVSecurityGroupDriver because of a NotImplemented error.

Adds the security_group_updated method as noop in
HyperVSecurityGroupDriver, solving the issue.

Closes-Bug: #1512278

Change-Id: Ia5d6fca3c3a2f827ade850bb43fc7e434e934a22
(cherry picked from commit f432ec44a78c4871a48a669c2aa81b33350ff41a)

commit_message:
Update nodes-tagging spec

Normalize the tag data structure with a cross-ref table.
The current table structure is going to waste space if the
number of tags * nodes is large, which will affect performance
of the tag search API.

Change-Id: I3e96aae377998a4198cdeee3c9db10585f320f40

commit_message:
Disable clean step 'reset_ilo' for iLO drivers by default

Disable default execution of clean step 'reset_ilo' during automated
cleaning. Resetting of iLO is not required during every invocation
of automated cleaning.

Change-Id: I45a5542c8db339417916c64455eba0fae9c3f44a
Closes-Bug: 1542977

commit_message:
Log warning if ipmi_username/ipmi_password missing

Even though an empty ipmi_username and/or ipmi_password is valid, it is
often an error in configuration. Log a warning if either value is
missing.

Add unit tests showing that an unspecified username or an empty string
username are treated the same and will cause no user to be specified.

Add unit tests showing that an unspecified password or an empty string
password are treated the same and will cause a NULL (\0) password to be
used.

Change-Id: I384e210da3216fb9335c4c782d69e606026d4b97

commit_message:
Add tenant_id as topics for core elements

Add tenant_ids as topics for core elements in dragonflow
data model: lswitch, lport, lrouter.
When security groups patch is merged, we also need
to add this to security group.

implements blueprint: selective-topo-dist

Change-Id: I0f2a4b5e5bd36df482966b554b2e58095f1c044c

commit_message:
split the documentation to two files: design and use cases

Change-Id: I516bd7554dcc3f166007f8d8829de860e22e0f83
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/vitrage refs/changes/45/277745/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================= Vitrage Use Cases ================= Add Nova Instance ----------------- .. image:: ./images/add_nova_instance_flow.png :width: 100% :align: center #. Nova Synchronizer plugin queries all Nova instances, or gets a message bus notification about a new Nova instance #. Nova Synchronizer plugin sends corresponding events to the Entity Queue #. The Entity Processor polls the Entity Queue and gets the new Nova Instance event #. The Entity Processor passes the event to the Nova Instance Transformer plugin, which returns a Vertex with the instance data, and an edge to the host Vertex in the graph #. The Entity Processor adds the new vertex and edge to the Graph .. image:: ./images/add_nova_instance_graph.png :width: 100% :align: center Add Aodh Alarm -------------- .. image:: ./images/add_aodh_alarm_flow.png :width: 100% :align: center #. Aodh Synchronizer plugin queries all Aodh alarms, or gets a notification (TBD) about an Aodh alarm state change #. Aodh Synchronizer plugin sends corresponding events to the Entity Queue #. The Entity Processor polls the Entity Queue and gets the Aodh Alarm event, for example threshold alarm on Instance1 CPU #. The Entity Processor passes the event to the Aodh Alarm Transformer plugin, which returns a Vertex with the alarm data, and an edge to the instance Vertex #. The Entity Processor adds the new vertex and edge to the Graph .. image:: ./images/add_aodh_alarm_graph.png :width: 100% :align: center Nagios Alarm Causes Deduced Alarm --------------------------------- .. image:: ./images/nagios_causes_deduced_flow.png :width: 100% :align: center 5. (steps 1-5) Nagios Synchronizer plugin pushes a nagios alarm on a switch to the Entity Queue, which is converted by Nagios Transformer to a vertex and inserted to the Graph 6. The Evaluator is notified about a new Vertex (Nagios switch alarm) that was added to the graph 7. The Evaluator performs its calculations (TBD) and deduces that alarms should be triggered on every instance on every host attached to this switch 8. The Evaluator pushes alarms to the Entity Queue 9. The Evaluator asks the notifier to notify on these new alarms 10. Aodh Notifier creates new alarm definitions in Aodh, and sets their states to "alarm" .. image:: ./images/nagios_causes_deduced_graph.png :width: 100% :align: center Create RCA Insights ------------------- .. image:: ./images/rca_flow.png :width: 100% :align: center #. The Evaluator is notified of a new alarm. #. The Evaluator evaluates the templates and the Graph (TBD), and decides that there is a root cause relation between two alarms. It adds a "causes" edge to the Graph .. image:: ./images/rca_graph.png :width: 100% :align: center Note that in future versions the graph with RCA information may become more complex, for example: .. image:: ./images/complex_rca_graph.png :width: 100% :align: center

commit_message:
Don't recompute metadata after clearing a user hook

Clearing a user hook is one class of signal that never results in a need to
recalculate the stack metadata, regardless of the resource type.

Change-Id: I555794e6ad3f6ffa43969f37d35766e3556e6fbb
Closes-Bug: #1542455
(cherry picked from commit d98c16fb0cda77ff8cf65769519bef98cce568e9)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/75/276975/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: result = res.signal({'unset_hook': 'pre-create'}) self.assertFalse(result) result = res.signal({'unset_hook': 'pre-update'}) self.assertFalse(result)

commit_message:
Fix incorrect result of listing private template

Previously, it returns all templates belong to tenant when only
requests private templates. The root cause is tenant filter overwrite
is_public filter by mistake. So fixed it and enhanced the test case
to make sure it only return private templates.

Change-Id: I382dd1e368df531898ca5431c85f5755b75bf4a2
Closes-Bug: #1540709
