commit_message:
support xbzrle compress for live migration

This spec describes the blueprint live-migrate-support-xbzrle-compress

DocImpact

Co-Authored-By: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Eli Qiao <liyong.qiao@intel.com>
Co-Authored-By: Yuntong Jin <yuntong.jin@intel.com>
Change-Id: I680182ddc1dfc0e57f3dab85fb9fefd0d112aeff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/65/248465/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== support XBZRLE compress for live migration ========================================== Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/live-migrate-support-xbzrle-compress When using live migrations, an operator might want to have a possibility to increase success chance of migration with busy enterprise workloads on their instance. This spec proposes a new compression(XBZRLE) for live migration. Problem description =================== In some cases, operator can tolerate pause VM during live migration to stop memory writes on a VM. And there is a BP support this feature. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/245543 But in another cases, the users want to keep their workloads on their vm uninterrupted. By using XBZRLE we can reduce VM downtime and total live-migration time of VMs running memory write intensive workloads typical of large enterprise applications such as SAP ERP Systems, and generally speaking for any application with a sparse memory update pattern. Use Cases ---------- * As an operator of an OpenStack cloud, I would like do the live migration for some purpose, such as hypervisor load-balance or save energy. To ensure the SLA uninterrupted business, I observe there's still heavy workloads on the VM, I just simply enable XBZRLE, and the live migration complete successfully with it's help. * Some other projects, such as watcher that leverage nova, it make some strategy to do live migration for hypervisor load-balance or save energy. It enable the XBZRLE compress, and it can tune the XBZRLE cache by monitoring the XBZRLE status and hypervisor workloads. Proposed change =============== A new option compress will be added in migrate_server API. And it will be passed to libvirt/driver _live_migration_operation, then libvirt will enable the auto-converge capability of hypervisor. Now the compress option just support XBZRLE, we will support other compression methods, such as multi-thread compress. XBZRLE need to retrieve the old page content from an LRU cache (default size of 64 MB). So the cache size is a key performance for XBZRLE. Two APIs, set_live_migrate_parameters and get_live_migrate_parameters. These two APIs should be extensible to support parameters of other method compressions. Some users, such as watcher projecter may want to make an intelligent strategy to tune all kinds of parameters during live migration to make it finish with less downtime and duration time. In order to monitor the xbzrle cache statistics, it need to extend os-migrations to teturn a xbzrle cache field. Alternatives ------------ Alternative is not doing this and let operator enable compress manually through hypervisor. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- A new array compress will be added as optional, the json-schema as below:: { 'type': 'object', 'properties': { 'os-migrateLive': { 'type': 'object', 'properties': { 'block_migration': parameter_types.boolean, 'disk_over_commit': parameter_types.boolean, 'compress': { 'type': 'array', 'items': ["xbzrle"], }, 'host': host }, 'additionalProperties': False, }, }, 'required': ['os-migrateLive'], 'additionalProperties': False, } Here the compress type is an array, not enum, for some compress types are not exclusive. set xbzrle cache size for live migration. `POST /servers/{server_id}/{action}` Set Parameters Body:: { "set_live_migrate_parameters": 'xbzrle': { 'cache-size': parameter_types.positive_integer, }, } Get Parameters Body:: { "get_live_migrate_parameters": 'xbzrle': { 'cache-size': parameter_types.positive_integer, }, } Normal http response code: `200 Accepted` Response Body:: {"migrate_parameters": 'xbzrle': { 'cache-size': parameter_types.positive_integer, }, } Expected error http response code: `403 Forbidden` - The parameters can be set even the instance is not currently being live migrated. For instance, non admin user has management authority over the instance, but has not been granted the authority to set the migration parameters. Expected error http response code: `404 Not Found` - the instance does not exist extend os-migrations to get xbzrle-cache statistics. Response Body:: { "migrations": [ { "created_at": "2012-10-29T13:42:02.000000", "dest_compute": "compute2", "dest_host": "1.2.3.4", "dest_node": "node2", "id": 1234, "instance_uuid": "instance_id_123", "new_instance_type_id": 2, "old_instance_type_id": 1, "source_compute": "compute1", "source_node": "node1", "status": "Done", "updated_at": "2012-10-29T13:42:02.000000", "xbzrle-cache":{ "cache-size":67108864, "bytes":20971520, "pages":2444343, "cache-miss":2244, "cache-miss-rate":0.123, "overflow":34434 } }, ] } These changes need new microversion. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- User need specify compress type explicitly and set the compress parameters when they want hypervisor to do compress during live migration. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ShaoHe Feng <shaohe.feng@intel.com> Other contributors: will_add_more Work Items ---------- * A new option compress is added in migrate_server API. * Two extended API set_live_migrate_parameters and get_live_migrate_parameters are added. * extend os-migrations to get xbzrle-cache statistics. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unittest and funtional tests in Nova Documentation Impact ==================== Doc the API change in the API Reference: http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html References ========== None History ======= Mitaka: Introduced

subject: Speed up functional testing
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-08 15:57:44.000000000', 'files': ['test/functional/tests.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/87fc21c7cfcce2a3e23a84fddcfd1309cd884716', 'message': "Speed up functional testing

test/functional/tests.py:TestObjectVersioningUTF8 does not clean
up the versions files it creates because the class's multiple
inheritance is such that it does not call the tearDown method in
TestObjectVersioning.

As a result, any attempt to clean up account containers wastes
time retrying container delete requests. This occurs either in
the setUp for TestSloEnv, if the TestSlo class is included in a
test run, or in the tests.py package tearDown method.

On the author's dev machine this patch reduces the execution
time of functional tests in tests.py by approx 30% or 1 minute.

Change-Id: I8194672bf2ca82435df5868720b6a55a79b94413
"}]
commit_message:
Speed up functional testing

test/functional/tests.py:TestObjectVersioningUTF8 does not clean
up the versions files it creates because the class's multiple
inheritance is such that it does not call the tearDown method in
TestObjectVersioning.

As a result, any attempt to clean up account containers wastes
time retrying container delete requests. This occurs either in
the setUp for TestSloEnv, if the TestSlo class is included in a
test run, or in the tests.py package tearDown method.

On the author's dev machine this patch reduces the execution
time of functional tests in tests.py by approx 30% or 1 minute.

Change-Id: I8194672bf2ca82435df5868720b6a55a79b94413
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/65/277465/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _tear_down_files(self): try: # only delete files and not containers def tearDown(self): super(TestObjectVersioning, self).tearDown() self._tear_down_files() def tearDown(self): self._tear_down_files() super(TestObjectVersioningUTF8, self).tearDown()
deleted_lines: def tearDown(self): super(TestObjectVersioning, self).tearDown() try: # only delete files and not container

commit_message:
Duplicate location error should raise HTTPConflict

Now, when add or replace a duplicate location to an image, Glance
will rasie 400 HTTPBadRequest error, which is not correct. It should
raise 409 HTTPConflict to keep the same with Glance client.
The artifacts raise 400 as well.

APIimpact
Docimpact

Change-Id: I59fc7ced5cb717884bf9668359986e681af6e1f6
Closes-bug: #1520053

Allow force stop server in nova rest api

Add force-stop-server.rst

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/18/195418/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================== Allow force stop server in nova rest api ====================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nova-api-force-stop-server Current nova API does not support to force stop a server. Problem description =================== There is no way for end-user to force stop a server. Use Cases ---------- 1. User wants to force stop a server. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== Add a new microversion allowing force stopping a server via POST method. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- The method: "/v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers/action" With the method type POST. Will include an optional parameter "type" (xsd:string), with possible values "HARD" and "SOFT", default value "SOFT". The os-stop schema definition will include "type" as well: :: stop = { 'type': 'object', 'properties': { 'os-stop': { 'type': ['object', 'null'], 'properties': { 'type': { 'enum': ['HARD', 'Hard', 'hard', 'SOFT', 'Soft', 'soft'] } }, 'additionalProperties': False } }, 'required': ['os-stop'], 'additionalProperties': False } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Jun Xu (xujun@cmss.chinamobile.com) Work Items ---------- * Add a new microversion * python-novaclient support Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests and functional tests to be created. Documentation Impact ==================== The Nova driver documentation for nova stop API and CLI commands usage need to be updated. References ========== * Bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1465956 requesting this feature. History ======= None

commit_message:
Libvirt driver emulator threads placement policy

The Nova schedular determines CPU resource utilization and instance
CPU placement based on the number of vCPUs in the flavour. A number
of hypervisors have work that is performed in the host OS on behalf
of a guest instance, which does not take place in association with
a vCPU. This is currently unaccounted for in Nova scheduling and
cannot have any placement policy controls applied.

Change-Id: Ie3309323334e20b0b7104a69217aa622b46fa627
Blueprint: libvirt-emulator-threads-policy
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/93/225893/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Libvirt driver emulator threads placement policy ================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/libvirt-emulator-threads The Nova schedular determines CPU resource utilization and instance CPU placement based on the number of vCPUs in the flavour. A number of hypervisors have work that is performed in the host OS on behalf of a guest instance, which does not take place in association with a vCPU. This is currently unaccounted for in Nova scheduling and cannot have any placement policy controls applied. Problem description =================== The Nova schedular determines CPU resource utilization by counting the number of vCPUs allocated for each guest. When doing overcommit, as opposed to dedicated resources, this vCPU count is multiplied by an overcommit ratio. This utilization is then used to determine optimal guest placement across compute nodes, or within NUMA nodes. A number of hypervisors, however, perform work on behalf of a guest instance in an execution context that is not associated with the virtual instance vCPUs. With KVM / QEMU, there are one or more threads associated with the QEMU process which are used for the QEMU main event loop, asynchronous I/O operation completion, migration data transfer, SPICE display I/O and more. With Xen, if the stub-domain feature is in use, there is an entire domain used to provide I/O backends for the main domain. Nova does not have any current mechanism to either track this extra guest instance compute requirement in order to measure utilization, nor to place any control over its execution policy. The libvirt driver has implemented a generic placement policy for KVM whereby the QEMU emulator threads are allowed to float across the same pCPUs that the instance vCPUs are running on. IOW, the emulator threads will steal some time from the vCPUs whenever they have work to do. This is just about acceptable in the case where CPU over commit is being used. When guests want dedicated vCPU allocation though, there is a desire to be able to express other placement policies. For example, to allocate one or more pCPUs to be dedicated to a guest's emulator threads. This becomes even more important if Nova gains support for real-time workloads, as it will not be acceptable to allow emulator threads to steal time from real-time vCPUs. While it would be possible for the libvirt driver to add different placement policies, unless the concept of emulator threads is exposed to the schedular in some manner, CPU usage cannot be expressed in a satisfactory manner. Thus there needs to be a way to describe to the schedular what other CPU usage may be associated with a guest, and account for that during placement. Use Cases ---------- The users of dedicated (no overcommit) CPU guests, particular those with real-time schedular policy, will want to configure guests such that emulator threads are placed separately from vCPUs. This will be desired by the NFV community, as well as the other user groups described for the real-time spec. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== Each hypervisor has a different architecture, for example QEMU has emulator threads, while Xen has stub-domains. To avoid favouring any specific implementation, the idea is to present concept of a virtual instance having zero or more "system psuedo-CPUs". For example, we might say that all the various QEMU threads account for 1 system psuedo-CPU, while a Xen stub-domain's 2 vCPUs, may correspond to the 2 system psuedo-CPUs. Since the permitted vCPU allocation is recorded against the flavour, it is natural to use a flavour extra spec to express the number of system psuedo-CPUs. So the new property * hw:cpu_system=2 would say that this instance is to be considered to have 2 system psuedo-CPUs. If this is omitted, it is assumed that the value is zero. In the virt drivers, when reporting the available resources to the schedular, the 'vcpu_total' field value will have to be adjusted to include the hw:cpu_system value set for any running instances. When the BaseCoreFilter schedular filter is checking a host's suitability, instead of checking just the flavour vCPU count, it will have to include the hw:cpu_system value too. The over commit ratio will applied to the combined value. IOW, given a flavour with * vcpus=8 * hw:cpu_system=2 * cpu_overcommit=1.5 The filter will look for a host with free CPU resource equivalent to 15, instead of 12. The NUMA schedular filter will also need to be changed to account for the extra threads, which will in turn include changing the InstanceNUMATopology object. Specifically the object will be extended to have a new field specifying what NUMA node the system psuedo-CPUs should be placed on. In the libvirt driver, if hw:cpu_system is set then <emulatorpin> will be used to control where the QEMU emulator threads run, based on the mask determined by the NUMA filter. The current default logic of floating emulator threads across all host pCPUs associated with vCPUs will only be used if hw:cpu_system is not set. Finally, there can be cases where it is desirable to separate the system psuedo-CPUs from the main vCPUs, but where they don't need a full dedicatd host pCPU to run on. To allow this to be controlled there will be a second flavour extra spec * hw:cpu_system_policy=shared|dedicated Similarly to the current hw:cpu_policy parameter, this will indicate whether the system psuedo-CPUs are to be given dedicated pCPUs of their own, or whether they can be shared with other guest instances. This parameter can also be set on the image using hw_cpu_system_policy. Alternatives ------------ We could use a host level tunable to just reserve a set of host pCPUs for running emulator threads globally, instead of trying to account for it per instance. This would work in the simple case, but when NUMA is used, it is highly desirable to have more fine grained config to control emulator thread placement. When real-time or dedicated CPUs are used, it will be critical to separate emulator threads for different KVM instances. Another option is to hardcode an assumption that the vCPUs number set against the flavour implicitly includes 1 vCPUs for emulator. eg a vCPU value of 5 would imply 4 actual vCPUs and 1 system psuedo-vCPU. This would likely be extremely confusing to tenant users, and developers alike. Do nothing is always an option. If we did nothing, then it would limit the types of workload that can be run on Nova. This would have a negative impact inparticular on users making use of the dedicated vCPU feature, as there would be no way to guarantee their vCPUs are not pre-empted by emulator threads. It can be worked around to some degree with realtime by setting a fixed policy that the emulator threads only run on the vCPUs that have non-realtime policy. This requires that all guest OS using realtime are SMP, but some guest OS want realtime, but are only UP. Data model impact ----------------- The InstanceNUMATopology object will be extended to have a new field * cpuset_system=SetOfIntegersField() This field will defualt to None, so a schema migration change just adds the new column with no data. It will only be populated if the hw:cpu_system flavour extra_spec is used and the NUMA filter is enabled, which will not be the case for any existing running instances. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ The NUMA and compute schedular filters will have some changes to them, but it is not anticipated that they will become more computationally expensive to any measurable degree. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers who are using dedicated CPU policy will wish to consider whether they want to also assign a number of system psuedo-CPUs for instances. This will involve setting up at most two extra flavour extra spec properties. Developer impact ---------------- Developers of other virtualization drivers may wish to make use of the new flavour extra spec property and schedular accounting. This will be of particular interest to the Xen hypervisor, if using the stub domain feature. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: berrange Other contributors: sahid Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ The realtime spec is not a pre-requisite, but is complementary to this work * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/libvirt-real-time * https://review.openstack.org/#/c/139688/ Testing ======= This can be tested in any CI system that is capable of testing the current NUMA and dedicated CPUs policy. ie, it requires ability to use KVM, not merely QEMU. Documentation Impact ==================== The documentation detailing NUMA and dedicated CPU policy usage will need to be extended to also describe the new options this work introduces. References ========== None

In the multi hypervisor OpenStack environment using such as
KVM, VMware, Hyper-V etc, we need to provide Cinder storage
backends corresponding to these hypervisors for booting a instance
from a volume. For example, VMware needs VMDK Cinder backend,
Hyper-V needs Windows Cinder backend and also KVM needs
supported backends such as LVM, ceph etc. KVM can't boot from
VMDK backend.

However, there is no way to specify storage backend when we boot
an instance from volume. As a result, the boot volume might be
created on unrelated backend then the volume boot will fail.

To boot an instance from specific combination of hypervisor and
storage backend, Nova should support volume_type argument when
Nova creates a new volume for attaching the instance.

commit_message:
Volume support for multi hypervisors

In multi hypervisor OpenStack environment using such as
KVM, VMware, Hyper-V etc, we need to provide Cinder storage
backends corresponding to these hypervisors for booting an
instance from a volume. For example, VMware needs VMDK Cinder
backend, Hyper-V needs Windows Cinder backend and also KVM needs
supported backends such as LVM, ceph etc. KVM can't boot from
VMDK backend.

However, there is no way to specify storage backend when we boot
an instance from a volume. As a result, the boot volume might be
created on unrelated backend then the volume boot will fail.

To boot an instance from specific combination between hypervisor
and storage backend, Nova should pass hypervisor_type as a hint
of Cinder filter scheduler when Nova creates a new volume for
attaching the instance.

Blueprint: volume-support-for-multi-hypervisors
Change-Id: I887952f5b14f8fb3b4bffac7fffd311725d90aad
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/86/245986/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================== Volume support for multi hypervisors ==================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/volume-support-for-multi-hypervisors Currently we can't specify Cinder storage backend during boot from volume. This causes a boot problem if we have multi hypervisors(HVs), multi storage backends and if only specific combination is permitted between HVs and storage backends. Problem description =================== In the multi hypervisor OpenStack environment using such as KVM, VMware, Hyper-V etc, we need to provide Cinder storage backends corresponding to these hypervisors for booting a instance from a volume. For example, VMware needs VMDK Cinder backend, Hyper-V needs Windows Cinder backend and also KVM needs supported backends such as LVM, ceph etc. KVM can't boot from VMDK backend. However, there is no way to specify storage backend when we boot an instance from volume. As a result, the boot volume might be created on unrelated backend then the volume boot will fail. To boot an instance from specific combination of hypervisor and storage backend, Nova should support volume_type argument when Nova creates a new volume for attaching the instance. Use Cases --------- This feature enables specific combination between hypervisor and storage backend to boot an instance from volume without failure. Proposed change =============== Using extra-specs at Cidner, we can associate a volume_type to a specific storage backend. This is an example that the volume_type "lvm-type" is associated to volume_backend_name "lvm" via extra-specs. :: $ cinder extra-specs-list +--------------+----------+----------------------------------+ | ID | Name | extra_specs | +--------------+----------+----------------------------------+ | 0020cd38-... | lvm-type | {u'volume_backend_name': u'lvm'} | +--------------+----------+----------------------------------+ Therefore, we need to support volume_type at Nova then we can create a volume on the specific volume backend during boot sequence of an instance. We need to support these two functionalities. * Add support for specifying the volume backend for Cinder through the volume_type configuration option, so that it can be requested through flavor extra-specs. * Add support for specifying the volume_type option as an optional argument of block_device_mapping_v2 object in the os-block-device-mapping API, so that user can boot an instance with specific volume type(backend) using the option. Alternatives ------------ Create number of availability zones based on the combination of HVs and storage backends. And then, create multiple cinder.conf includes corresponding availability zone name of storage backend individually. This is not an ideal usage of availability zones. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- POST ``/v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers`` supports new string argument "volume_type" in the block_device_mapping_v2 object. :: POST /v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers { "server": { "name": "volboot", "imageRef": "", "flavorRef": "", "metadata": {}, "personality": [], "block_device_mapping_v2": [ { "source_type": "image", "boot_index": "0" "uuid": "fake-volume-id-1", "volume_size": "1" "destination_type": "volume", "delete_on_termination": "True", "volume_type" : "lvm-type" } ] } } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mtanino <mitsuhiro.tanino@hds.com> Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Add support for specifying the volume backend for Cinder through the volume_type configuration option, so that it can be requested through flavor extra-specs. * Add support for specifying the volume_type option as an optional argument of block_device_mapping_v2 object in the os-block-device-mapping API, so that user can boot an instance with specific volume type(backend) using the option. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit and functional test cases needs to be added. Documentation Impact ==================== API change needs to be documented: * Compute API extensions documentation. http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html References ========== None History ======= None

commit_message:
Add a binding type negotiation between Nova and Neutron

Change the Nova-Neutron interface in a backward compatible way so that
Neutron ports are bound using Nova's expressed preference of APIs.

This allows Neutron to select the appropriate binding_type according
to its abilities and the preference of supporting hypervisor
drivers.

Change-Id: Iad1c76240680d8415a0f433483cc8b33817382ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/17/190917/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================================== Improve Nova-Neutron port binding through negotiation ===================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nova-neutron-binding-negotiation Nova currently requests that Neutron bind a port and then attaches a VM to the results of the binding. We would like to make this a negotiated process (while maintaining backward compatibility) to make it easier for Neutron drivers to select the right binding type for the circumstances, and we would like to make Neutron be more explicit in what it is doing in its return value to Nova. Problem description =================== The binding process is mainly driven by a lot of tacitly agreed information: - Neutron knows which binding type to give Nova to suit Nova's hypervisor backend (as different hypervisors support different binding types) - Nova can predict, when it's told that a binding has happened, many pieces of information, including the names of bridges and veths that Neutron will create This leaves three problems: 1. Nova cannot say that binding types are sometimes available and sometimes not - for instance, vhostuser is available when a VM is started with a hugepage flavor and not otherwise, or vhostuser with a compute host running KVM and something else for a different compute host running a different hypervisor. 2. Neutron cannot easily provide different binding types in different circumstances - for instance, vhostuser in some cases and virtio in others based on a user expressed preference 3. Nova must have code added for new binding types that is in perfect sync with Neutron; Neutron has to be correctly configured to dodge absent binding_types Use Cases ---------- When using a driver that supports vhostuser, you want want it to use vhostuser in some circumstances and fall back to virtio in others. For instance: - vhostuser when hugepages are on, but - virtio when it's off, and - virtio when the hw_vif_type is set to an unsuitable value on the image (since vhostuser compels a VM to use the virtio VIF type internally) In this case, Nova would be able to express its preference - vhostuser when it's possible, virtio in all cases - and Neutron's code would be able to choose from the available options based on what it could implement. The interface would be the best available to both sides that satisfies the requirement. When using a plugging type that creates an interface, the interface name should be returned from Neutron to Nova, which should use it in preference to guessing the name. This means that rather than having two perfectly synced pieces of code to create arbitrary name values on both sides, the name generation is the sole responsibility of Neutron. This actually works today, but the older plugging types don't make use of the facility; we propose making this the default. Project Priority ----------------- None. Proposed change =============== When Nova calls Neutron it will populate the vif binding:profile with a 'preferred_binding_types' field containing a comma separated list, (with optional, ignored spaces) of binding types it can make use of to Neutron. The Neutron driver should treat this list of types as the supported and preferred list of types. The binding types in the list will consist of a bracketed list containing binding_type strings. The name of the binding_type indicates the contract between Nova and Neutron that determines where packets will land (e.g. a TAP device, a bridge, an OVS port; and potentially, agreement on the naming of that element or other identifying information), as it does now. The preferred_binding_types are a recommendation and not a requirement to Neutron. As such, Nova should assume that it may be ignored, resulting in the following three rules: - Older Neutron implementations will ignore this and return a binding type from the currently existing set. Nova must reject any binding that is not in the list and otherwise bind using that binding_type. Nova can assume that Neutron has chosen its first supported value from the list of preferences provided. This maintains current behaviour. - Newer Neutron implementations will change behaviour. When they see this value, they will use this in determining a binding type to use. They will choose the first binding type they support. Note that the binding types supported by Neutron may change due to additional information in the binding:profile; for instance, if the binding:profile expresses a desire for SR-IOV then the Neutron driver may choose to only support an SR-IOV binding and return that preference (providing Nova is willing to accept it). - Neutron will return binding_failed if no type given is supported. Neutron can be trusted to use a preconfigured binding_type if no preference is passed, maintaining historical behaviour in the face of a hypervisor driver that does not support the new protocol, or an older version of Nova. That is, no expression of preference is read as 'use your own best judgement'. A notable example of what could be done: with libvirt/kvm, the 'vhostuser' binding type will only appear in the preferences list if the memory of the VM is going to be stored in a shared file that qemu will hold open (at the moment, this implies that hugepages are set in the flavor). This is a requirement for a successful vhostuser binding. The adjustment of preferences according to circumstance ensures that Neutron does not use a vhostuser binding when the Nova VM cannot make use of it. In a future change (for which a separate spec will be added), we will propose a set of more modern binding_types that simplify the Nova code. These will be listed as preferential. Thanks to this negotiation, they will be used if and only if both sides support them. At some point in the future, the old types may then be deprecated. The code change will involve changing the drivers to pass the preferred_binding_type information to Neutron during the binding process. Alternatives ------------ This is a means to improve communication between Nova and Neutron, and as such is not essential. A valid alternative is to do nothing. Other options have not been considered. Until Nova actually declares valid options to Neutron, the vhostuser binding type will not work in many cases. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- Nova will pass information in the binding:profile dictionary to be consumed by neutron. Neutron's port binding extension will modified to define the optional 'preferred_binding_types' within binding:profile. Neutron L2 plugins supporting preferred_binding_types will choose the first binding_type listed that they support and return a port binding of that type. Historical plugins, or old Neutron versions, will return a binding type as today. If the binding type is not within the set that Nova requested, Nova will log the fact and treat the binding as failed. Security impact --------------- Care must be taken to ensure that incorrect Neutron-returned values are with the valid set, or Nova may take inappropriate actions that could in the worst case pose a security risk. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- When changing the virt drivers developers must consider changes to the preferred binding type list. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ijw-ubuntu Other contributors: sean-k-mooney mleroy Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ We do not depend on, but must be wary of, the currently active refactoring of the Nova code for Neutron binding. Testing ======= Confirm that Nova is passing an accepted binding type list during binding and that it is respected. Confirm that Nova accepts and reacts correctly to supported, unsupported and out-of-list binding types. Documentation Impact ==================== The Nova-Neutron interface is poorly documented and should be comprehensively documented as a part of this change, in dev documentation. References ========== None. History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Liberty - Introduced

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================= Pagination for hypervisor ========================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/pagination-for-hypervisor This spec is proposed to support pagination for hypervisor. Problem description =================== When there are thousands of compute nodes, it would be slow to get the whole hypervisor list, and it is bad for user experience to display thousands of items in a table in horizon. Use Cases ---------- * Get paginated compute nodes list when there are too many items. Proposed change =============== Changes are going to be in the following places: * DB api `compute_node_get_all` will be refactored by adding params limit, marker, sort_key, and sort_dir. * Compute node object `get_all` method will be refactored to support pagination. * Compute api `compute_node_get_all` will be refactored. * REST API microversion will be added for hypervisors list to accept pagination request. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- New Hypervisors list API to support pagination: request:: GET /v2.1/{tenant_id}/os-hypervisors?marker=2&limit=1 reponse:: { "hypervisors": [ { "hypervisor_hostname": "fake-mini", "id": 3, "state": "up", "status": "enabled" } ] } Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: liyingjun Work Items ---------- 1. Change db api to support pagination params. 2. Refactor compute api for compute node `get_all`. 3. Add REST API microversion. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= The changes will be exercised through unit tests. Documentation Impact ==================== REST API microversion 2.13 will be added. References ========== None

commit_message:
Configurable Resource Tracker

The class used for the resource tracker is hard-coded in nova, which
limits flexibility when experimenting with new designs. This spec calls
for changing that to a configurable option.

Blueprint: configurable-resource-tracker
Change-Id: If30d0dc689525399d2023e6cd21a28c51ab77769
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/40/245940/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================= Add Configurable Resource Tracker ================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/configurable-resource-tracker There is a lot of interest in making the nova scheduler able to stand on its own, so that it can then be used by other services. There is also interest in improving the scheduler by experimenting with alternative designs. Nearly all of the classes involved in the scheduler process are configurable, except the Resource Tracker. Problem description =================== Nova uses the Scheduler to determine how to best fulfill a request by matching available resources in its hosts to the requirements of the request. It does this by writing this resource information to a database, which the Scheduler then reads. The gathering of resource information and writing to the database is done by the compute node's resource tracker, and the reading and comparison of this information is doen by the Scheduler's host manager. All of the components on the scheduler side of things are configurable: you can substitute any scheduler driver you wish, as well as the host manager class that is used by the driver. But on the compute side, the class used for the resource tracker is hard-coded. The result of this hard-coding is that the possible alternative designs for the scheduler are limited to only those which work with the data as it currently exists. There are designs that envision using Kafka, Cassandra, and others to handle the flow of resource information to/from the Scheduler that have potential to make Nova perform much better in some situations, but these are precluded from consideration and experimental testing because of this hard-coded limit. Likewise, direct claiming of resources by the scheduler in these alternative designs is similarly precluded. Use Cases --------- As an operator of a large OpenStack deployment, I would like to have Nova more rapidly and reliably deploy instances than the current scheduler is capable of doing. As a Nova developer, I would like to experiment with alternative designs for the interface between compute and the scheduler. Proposed change =============== Remove the direct import of nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker from nova/compute/manager.py. A new entry point will be defined, and stevedore will be used to load the configured class. This will require a new configuration option 'resource_tracker_class', which will default to the existing ResourceTracker class. Alternatives ------------ One alternative that has been suggested is to make the nova/scheduler/client classes configurable, because this is how the ResourceTracker actually does the writing of the data. A different client class could instead take the data in the ResourceTracker object and write it whatever store/transport that was desired. There are two problems with this approach, though. First, it isn't a good design match, as it doesn't make sense to change the scheduler's client, which ideally should handle communication from any other service, just to fit the needs of one method of one particular service. Second, and more importantly, it doesn't solve the problem of how an alternative scheduler implementation could communicate back to compute for things such as claims. Without a configurable ResourceTracker, claims have to be handled as they are now. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ Using stevedore to load the ResourceTracker instead of a direct import may add a few milliseconds to the startup of a compute node, but I doubt it will be noticeable. Other deployer impact --------------------- A new configuration option will be added, but unless they are deploying an experimental scheduler variation, they will not need to do anything to have things run the way they currently do. In the future, if any of these experiments yield useful alternatives, deployers may want to configure this config opt as well as the others to specify the classes for the alternative approach. Developer impact ---------------- For most developers, this will have no impact. For those developers investigating alternative scheduler designs, this will enable them to explore options that are not currently possible. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Ed Leafe <ed-leafe> Work Items ---------- * Add an entry point for the resource tracker class to setup.cfg * Modify compute/manager.py to add a config option for the resource tracker, and to use that for instantiating in _get_resource_tracker(). Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= A test of the configuration option will be added, so that we verify that changing the option properly changes the class instantiated for the resource tracker. Documentation Impact ==================== Since this adds a config option, a reno entry documenting it will be required. References ========== Blog on the idea of running scheduler experiments: http://blog.leafe.com/reimagining_scheduler/ Dev list email thread, starting with: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-October/076373.html History =======

subject: [WIP] SSH host certificates
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-25 06:29:19.000000000', 'files': ['specs/mitaka/approved/ssh-host-certificates.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/0e89f6ce9fa48f4bc1750f64bd94b2daa129bec9', 'message': "[WIP] SSH host certificates

RFC:

While the idea is possible to implement and will work, there's a problem
of secure host key storage left. The host keys should not be permamently
available in nova's database.

The most trivial way to achieve it would be to periodically clean host
keys created X minutes ago. (so certainly after the host booted and had
the chance to copy it) Another option would be to make the metadata
writable/erasable, but that's going against the current design.

Yet another option would be to only allow host key signing where direct
access to the spawned instance is available before boot (libguestfs,
etc.) This has the extra benefit of not preserving the key in the
database at all.

Suggestions, alternatives and comments on the rest of the spec welcome.

Change-Id: Ie56634789ba3ac92f9a59110bc66d37f1a7c74dd
"}]
commit_message:
[WIP] SSH host certificates

RFC:

While the idea is possible to implement and will work, there's a problem
of secure host key storage left. The host keys should not be permamently
available in nova's database.

The most trivial way to achieve it would be to periodically clean host
keys created X minutes ago. (so certainly after the host booted and had
the chance to copy it) Another option would be to make the metadata
writable/erasable, but that's going against the current design.

Yet another option would be to only allow host key signing where direct
access to the spawned instance is available before boot (libguestfs,
etc.) This has the extra benefit of not preserving the key in the
database at all.

Suggestions, alternatives and comments on the rest of the spec welcome.

Change-Id: Ie56634789ba3ac92f9a59110bc66d37f1a7c74dd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/86/227686/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================ Support for signed SSH host keys ================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/ssh-host-certificates Add support for SSH host certificates to Nova. This allows users to trust the instance they connect to, without relying on the current assumption that the first connection always reaches the trusted host. It also simplifies the first connection during high churn of instances. Problem description =================== There are two aspects of the first connection to a new instance which are not optimal right now. The first issue is that the user must trust they're connecting to the right host. There are situations like IP address typos and configuration errors which can lead to connections to unexpected hosts. Since the new host key is usually not known at this point, that user cannot easily tell that they've reached untrusted host. The second issue is that instances reusing old IPs will have entries in :file:`.ssh/known_hosts` that do not match the host key anymore. Use Cases ---------- 1. After registering an SSH signing key with Nova, user can connect to a new instance and be sure it's one of their instances. 2. After registering an SSH signing key with Nova, user can terminate and spawn new instances reusing the same IPs without the need to remove cached :file:`.ssh/known_hosts` entries. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== Three components require a change to support this blueprint: Nova, novaclient, CloudInit. Nova requires a change which allows it to store SSH private keys for a project, generate and sign host keys, and publish the host keys along with the certificate in the instance metadata. Then it requires an API update to support uploading (or generating) and deleting said keys. All of those operations correspond closely to what currently happens with SSH pubic keys - this should allow a lot of code reuse. novaclient requires a change to interact with the API defined above. This should also be very similar to existing SSH public key operations. CloudInit requires a change to read the SSH host key and certificate from the instance metadata and write them to the file that ``sshd`` can use. ``sshd`` must be configured before the first run, or alternatively it can be restarted after new keys are in place. Alternatives ------------ Some distributions print out the host key to the console output, which can be then used by the user to verify the instance. This is not standardised in any way and not required. It requires custom scripting to support. Another way to obtain a trusted host key is to request signing inside of cloudinit itself, however this again requires trusting a newly created instance and potentially making the metadata service an RPC endpoint rather than readonly service. Instead of creating a new set of routes, keys could be stored along existing SSH keypairs. This is a bad idea in case user confuses the meaning of keypairs. It would also require adding new information to existing key listing. Data model impact ----------------- This change requires only additions to schemas. New table needs to store the following information: * project id * SSH CA (signing) key * key type (``dsa``, ``ecdsa``, ``ed25519``, ``rsa``) * standard attributes (creation/deletion information and unique id) The instance table needs a new column referencing the host key id. Initially this should be unassigned (NULL) for all existing instances. REST API impact --------------- A set of ``GET``, ``POST``, ``DELETE`` endpoints will be created, corresponding to ones already implemented for ``os-keypairs``. These should be available for routes: :: /v2/{tenant_id}/os-sshca /v2/{tenant_id}/os-sshca/{name} Route ``POST /v2/{tenant_id}/servers`` will require an additional parameter to specify the SSH CA key. Security impact --------------- This change introduces a new secret/private element into the database. Host key signing requires Nova to hold this key and only sign instances started by the related project. In the future, this function could be optionally delegated to a Barbican service instead. In practice there's no new danger for the ``sshd`` communication itself. While the host key is generated and deployed by Nova now, similar capability was already possible using file injections or just modifying the image before. A compromised Nova instance does not gain any new capabilities from this change. Generated host keys MUST be isolated from other users or the system and deleted as soon as they're loaded into metadata. Notifications impact -------------------- Uploading, modifying, deleting SSH signing keys should result in an audit trail - possibly via CADF messages. Other end user impact --------------------- To use the new functionality user needs to explicitly enable it by uploading or generating the key and by enabling it on the new instance. Modification of exisiting instances is not trivial and would not be supported. Proposed new calls for host SSH key management. Following ``ssh-keygen`` documentation, the signing key is called the Certificate Authority key, so the prefix is ``ssh-ca``: nova ssh-ca-add [--priv-key <priv-key>|[--key-type <type>]] <name> nova ssh-ca-delete <name> nova ssh-ca-list nova ssh-ca-show <name> The optional ``--priv-key`` option decides if the key is uploaded from the user, or generated on server side. If the key is not provided, an optional ``--key-type`` option defines type of key is it. Possible options are ``dsa``, ``ecdsa``, ``ed25519``, ``rsa``. (``rsa1`` should not be supported) Similarily to SSH keypairs, the CA private key should not be possible to download once it's generated. (even though the system keeps a copy of it) If the new signing key is generated by Nova, it does not need to be displayed to the user. ``ssh-ca-show`` command should only show the public key, formatted for use in SSH :file:``known_hosts`` Instance spawning also requires a new parameter: nova boot ... --ssh-ca <name> ... Documentation has to include the fact that when ``--ssh-ca`` is specified, the ssh host key is generated by the cloud infrastructure, not the instance. There's a new failure mode possible when booting a host: the SSH CA key has a limited lifetime and may not be valid anymore at the time of the request. This should result in a clear error message. Performance Impact ------------------ Generating new host keys and signing them has a cost on the order of tens of milliseconds. In comparison to other operations in the instance creation process, it should not be noticable. Instance boot time should be faster by the same amount of time since it doesn't need to generate the key anymore. Other deployer impact --------------------- SSH utilities need to be available to Nova, which should be the case on all UNIX-like deployments by default, but may need extra configuration on other systems. In the first iteration, only ``ssh-keygen`` from OpenSSH project will be supported to simplify implementation. For systems with customised ACL / MAC systems, it may be necessary to adjust the rules to allow the ``nova-api`` process to run the ``ssh-keygen`` command. Developer impact ---------------- None (this is an isolated feature) Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: stanislaw-pitucha Other contributors: welcome to join Work Items ---------- * nova-api: SSH CA key upload, generation, management * nova-api: SSH host key generation and signing on instance creation * nova-api: populating metadata with SSH host key and certificate * novaclient: SSH CA key management * novaclient: instance creation parameter for host key spawning * cloudinit: provisioning the SSH host key and certificate onto the instance Dependencies ============ SSH utilities for key generation need to be present on the host. Testing ======= * End to end key management (create, upload, show, delete) * Other projects cannot access signing key * Expired host keys prevent creation of instance if host key signing is requested * Instance gets created with signed host key, if configured (tempest test) Documentation Impact ==================== New novaclient and nova options. Short section about what SSH host certificates are and why are they useful. References ========== * `Explanation of SSH certificates`_ * `OpenSSH announcement`_ History ======= Optional section for Mitaka intended to be used each time the spec is updated to describe new design, API or any database schema updated. Useful to let reader understand what's happened along the time. .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced :: _Explanation of SSH certificates: https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-create-an-ssh-ca-to-validate-hosts-and-clients-with-ubuntu :: _OpenSSH announcement: http://www.openssh.com/txt/release-5.4

commit_message:
Inheritable admin image properties

Make some image properties inheritable when snapshotting or shelving an
instance, even though the user does not have the permission to create them.

Change-Id: Ie7b1e9d00df97079a6f8ecd8d93575e1d551951e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/31/206431/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== inheritable admin image properties ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/inheritable-admin-image-properties Make some image properties inheritable when snapshotting or shelving an instance, even though the user does not have the permission to create them. Problem description =================== An image in glance can have custom properties with CRUD rules depending on user-roles. When snapshotting or shelving an instance, nova creates a new image in glance using the user credentials. If the user does not have the permission to create one of the custom properties he is not able to create an image, thus he is not able to snapshot or shelve the instance. Use Cases ---------- A cloud-administrator wants to store license-cost properties on a per-image basis (like how much to charge per hour per cpu). This property can be protected by role, but a cloud owner will want this property to be automatically inherited to child images. Another use case would be an administrator who wants to make operations on instances depending on image properties. For example tagging Windows instances so they are run on a specific aggregate. The administrator wants this tag to be inherited automatically, but he does not want the user to be able to change this property. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== We propose to create the option "inheritable_admin_image_properties" containing a list of inheritable custom properties. After creation of the image from snapshotting or shelving the instance, those properties will be set by nova using its admin credentials. Alternatives ------------ An alternative would be to create this functionality in glance. However we do not think it is the way to do it since glance behaves like a simple object store. Inheritance is defined by custom properties which leads us back to our problem. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- This change requires elevated privilege. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ With the option enabled there should be a performance impact as the request will get a new token for elevated authentication. Other deployer impact --------------------- A new option will be available in the config file of nova : inheritable_admin_image_properties Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Marc Fouch Other contributors: Work Items ---------- * Change the behavior in compute.api * Create function in image.api * Create function in image.glance * Unit tests Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests. Documentation Impact ==================== This new feature should be added to the documentation. References ========== Example of image metadata : http://docs.openstack.org/image-guide/content/image-metadata.html Old blueprint with same issue : https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/inherited-image-property-support History ======= None

commit_message:
Get quota and usage from neutron for limit APIs spec

Blueprint URL:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/limits-quota-usage-from-neutron

Change-Id: I6744899193293de68ede50e12e51fd5949c973c3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/35/206735/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ..Get quota and usage from neutron for limit APIs limits-quota-usage-from-neutron This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================================== Get quota and usage from neutron for limit APIs =============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/limits-quota-usage-from-neutron On a system configured to use Neutron, for the limits API, we should retrieve quota and usage for floating IPs and security groups from Neutron, rather than Nova DB. Problem description =================== If Neutron is configured in an Openstack installation and the Nova quota and usage APIs are called, incorrect data from the Nova database will be returned to the caller, since Nova is not currently proxying Neutron to get the correct information. Use Cases ---------- As a cloud administrator, I need accurate networking information returned from the Nova limits API, whether or not if Neutron is configured in my cloud. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== This change will be made in the v3 limits and used_limits controllers. The v2 API will not be changed and will operate the same as it always has operated. v2.1 will operate as it currently does also. A new microversion, starting at version 2.2 will be used for the UsedLimitsController and LimitsController. In this microversion, a check will be made to determine if Neutron is configured. If it is configured, a proxy call will be made to the following Neutron APIs: * list_floatingips * list_security_groups * show_quota A previous patch implementation can be found here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/43822/ The plan is to update the above patch, so comment and change history is persisted. The following changes need to be made in the patch: * The above patch is coded using the v2 API. This will be moved to v3 instead * v2 limits and used_limits controllers changes will be reverted * Tests will be updated to call the 2.2 microversion * All stale, unmerged method calls will be updated to use the latest APIs Alternatives ------------ * 1. fail - Patch located here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/199604/ - Since we already return data, which is incorrect, it is more consistent to continue returning data, but the correct data * 2. return -1 or some other indicator for floating ips and security groups indicating that Nova doesn't know the information without going to Neutron. - Not a great solution since we don't give a reason why we aren't returning the data Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Addition of microversion 2.2 for UsedLimitsController and LimitsController controllers. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ There will be a small amount of overhead while calling the Neutron API, but the performance impact should be minimal. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: * Cale Rath <ctrath@us.ibm.com> Other contributors: * Matt Riedemann <mriedem@us.ibm.com> * GuoHui Liu <guohliu@cn.ibm.com> Work Items ---------- * Add v2.2 microversion * Update original patch - rebase with master and update accordingly to any code changes that can't be merged * Remove code from v2 API * Move API proxy code to v2.2 UsedLimitsController and LimitsController * Add additional microversion tests Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Test v2.2 with Neutron configured * Test v2.2 without Neutron configured * Test v2 and v2.1 to ensure Neutron data is not returned * Test passthru of errors from Neutron Documentation Impact ==================== API documentation for the Nova limits API should be updated to state the 2.2 microversion updates References ========== * Original patch - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/43822/ * Alternative 1 patch - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/43822/ * http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/devref/api_microversions.html * Microversion example - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/168966/ History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced

commit_message:
Returning Compute Node IP address in hypervisor list

APIImpact
adds new attribute to hypervisor-list API

blueprint os-hypervisors-ipaddress

Change-Id: I8363474dc82f5705727825c91a23007ec5721560
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/07/215207/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================================== Returning Compute Node IP address in hypervisor list ==================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/os-hypervisors-ipaddress This spec provides the host_ip of the compute nodes in 'nova hypervisor-list' api call. Problem description =================== As part of the blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/no- compute-fanout-to-scheduler we store the 'host_ip' and 'supported_instances' into compute_nodes table. But while getting the hypervisor-list we get only the ID and hostname. Use Cases ---------- None Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== We are not modifying the DB as the data is already stored in compute_nodes table. We are changing nova API to add one more attribute to the JSON it returns. The attribute name is 'host_ip'. And we also require to change Nova client to display the Host IP column in the table as follows. +----+---------------------+-------------------+ | ID | Hypervisor hostname | Host IP | +----+---------------------+-------------------+ | 1 | PRINHYLTPHP0334 | 192.168.122.23 | +----+---------------------+-------------------+ Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- The proposed change just updates the GET response data in the HypervisorManager.list API. Request: GET --header "X-OpenStack-Nova-API-Version: 2.xx" /v2/{tenant-id}/os-hypervisors Response: :: { "hypervisors":[ { "status":"enabled", "state":"up", "id":1, "hypervisor_hostname":"PRINHYLTPHP0334", "host_ip":"192.168.122.23" } ] } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- * The python-novaclient hypervisor-list command could be updated to show the host_ip in it's output. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Bharath Thiruveedula<bharath_ves@hotmail.com> Work Items ---------- * Return 'host_ip' attribute in addition to ID and Hypervisor hostname. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Unit tests and possibly API samples functional tests in the nova tree. Documentation Impact ==================== The nova/api/openstack/rest_api_version_history.rst document will be updated. References ========== None History ======= None

is created from --ephemeral param when nova boot the instance.

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================== Allow increase ephemeral disk during resize ===================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/allow_increase_ephemeral_disk_during_resize Allow increase ephemeral disk during resize NOTE: this bp is in early stage, only want to collect info and opinion on whether it's worthy to do so and additional work will be done on the bp such as API changes and work items etc. Problem description =================== This idea is coming from discussion during [1]. Currently we allow resize an instance to a flavor with bigger ephemeral disk size. However, if the previous disks are created through --ephemeral parameter, the resize operation will not affect them and user have no way to update those disks. step 1: create a flavor with ephemeral disk 20G [jichen@compute1 ~]$ nova flavor-create --ephemeral 20 jit2 122 512 1 1 +-----+------+-----------+------+-----------+------+-------+-------------+ | ID | Name | Memory_MB | Disk | Ephemeral | Swap | VCPUs | RXTX_Factor | +-----+------+-----------+------+-----------+------+-------+-------------+ | 122 | jit2 | 512 | 1 | 20 | | 1 | 1.0 | +-----+------+-----------+------+-----------+------+-------+-------------+ step 2: nova boot --image e088edb0-5109-4d1c-896d-4b2937522007 --flavor 122 --nic net-id=71bda547-4346-438b-b494-06f257d8f749 --ephemeral size=1 --ephemeral size=1 j4 [jichen@compute1 ~]$ nova list +--------------------------------------+----+---------+-------------------+ | ID | N | Status | Networks | +--------------------------------------+----+---------+-------------------+ | aab7d856-c9a5-4fc3-b646-82c23c96f049 | j1 | SHUTOFF | private=10.0.0.3 | | 36d101fd-6f43-4ad6-840f-e1208c0dfc7c | j4 | ACTIVE | private=10.0.0.13 | +--------------------------------------+----+---------+-------------------+ step 3: create another flavor with following command nova flavor-create --ephemeral 30 jit3 123 512 1 1 use following resize command to resize instance: nova resize 36d101fd-6f43-4ad6-840f-e1208c0dfc7c 123 Return back to the folder and check the disk size. /opt/stack/data/nova/instances/36d101fd-6f43-4ad6-840f-e1208c0dfc7c disk.eph0 and disk.eph1 are there and the disk size is 1G So resize didn't make change to ephemeral disk and nova can't change the size of the existing ephemeral disk. Use Cases ---------- This is different to [1]; [1] is talking about create ephemeral disk after it is booted, this bp suggest to allow input params to resize operation so that the ephemeral disk size can be changed if the ephemeral disk is created through --ephemeral parameter. Project Priority ----------------- Not applicable Proposed change =============== Allow Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- TBD Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- End user is able to resize ephemeral disk as they want. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jichenjc Work Items ---------- TBD Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Functional cases for resize an ephemeral disk created from --ephemeral param. Documentation Impact ==================== Doc need to be updated to indicate API changes. References ========== [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/132614/

commit_message:
Support hypervisor_type option

Glance supports metadata to specify a hypervisor corresponding
to a glance image, but as a result, we should prepare multiple
images as many as hypervisors even if the images are almost same.

Supporting hypervior_type parameter through flavor extra-specs
could solve this problem.

Change-Id: I52c9f9912488a047a180711c071900aa2d497e17
Implements: blueprint support-hypervisor-type-option
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/54/246154/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================== Support hypervisor_type option ============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/support-hypervisor-type-option Glance supports metadata to specify a hypervisor corresponding to a glance image, but as a result, we should prepare multiple images as many as hypervisors even if the images are almost same. Supporting hypervior_type option through flavor extra-spec and adding same option to server API could solve this problem. Problem description =================== Currently, in order to deploy an instance to specific hypervisor, user needs to create an instance using a glance image which has hypervisor_type metadata. However using glance metadata, admin have to prepare images as many as hypervisors with setting hypervisor_type metadata previously. When we use hypervisor specific image types such as qcow2, vmdk, vhd, it is acceptable to prepare images as many as hypervisors, however if we use hypervisor non-specific image type such as raw format, same image should be available for KVM, Baremetal, Xen, LXC etc hypervisors. But using current glance metadata mechanish, we have to prepare image store region for each hypervisor even if we can share same image between multiple hypervisors. In order to solve the situation, * Nova supports hypervisor_type key which is defined in the extra-spec of flavor. * Nova supports hypervisor_type as an rgument for boot option of server API. Use Cases --------- * Hypervisor non-specific image type can be shared beteen multiple hypervisors and then this can reduce total usage of storage to store glance images. * User can deploy an instance to specific hypervisor by using new option in API without setting glance metadata beforehand. Proposed change =============== We need to support these three functionalities. * Add support for specifying the hypervisor type for Nova scheduler through the hypervisor_type configuration option, so that it can be requested through flavor extra-specs. * Add support for specifying the hypervisor_type option as an optional argument of `/v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers` API, so that user can boot an instance with specific volume type (backend) using the option. * Add hypervisor_type option support for python-novaclient. Alternatives ------------ Use current glance metadata implementation as is. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- POST ``/v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers`` supports new string argument "hypervisor_type". :: POST /v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers { "server": { "name": "volboot", "imageRef": "", "flavorRef": "", "metadata": {}, "personality": [], "block_device_mapping_v2": [ { "source_type": "image", "boot_index": "0" "uuid": "fake-volume-id-1", "volume_size": "1" "destination_type": "volume", "delete_on_termination": "True", } ], "hypervisor_type": "qemu", } } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mtanino <mitsuhiro.tanino@hds.com> Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Add support for specifying the hypervisor type for Nova scheduler through the hypervisor_type configuration option. * Add support for specifying the hypervisor_type option as an optional argument of `/v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers` API. * Add hypervisor_type option support for python-novaclient. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit and functional test cases needs to be added. Documentation Impact ==================== API change needs to be documented: * Compute API extensions documentation. http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html References ========== None History ======= None
